dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: A very high airplane view of the entire island. Over this Voice, authoritative, impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In any discussion of contemporary  America and how its people live, we  must inevitably start with --  Manhattan -- New York City, U.S.A!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan -- glistening, modern giant  of concrete and steel reaching to  the heavens and holding in its arms  seven millions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven millions -- happy beneficiaries  of the advantages and comforts this  gracious metropolis has to offer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its fine broad streets and boulevards  facilitate the New Yorker's carefree,  orderly existence.

dialogues.speaker: BROADWAY AND FORTY-SECOND STREET
dialogues.text: An enormous traffic jam, horns honking, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kindly, courteous public servants  ever on hand to offer a word of  friendly advice.

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFIC COP AND CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: yelling at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A transportation system second to  none in speed and comfort!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modern recreational facilities for  its children!

dialogues.speaker: A CROWDED LOWER EAST SIDE STREET
dialogues.text: Kids playing ball in truck-laden street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For its adults, the peace and privacy  of a day in the sun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's delightful changes in climate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its great institutions of learning!  Open to all. Free of charge.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING EXCAVATION
dialogues.text: Leaning on a railing looking down into the excavation are group of sidewalk supervisors. The CAMERA MOVES UP to a H CLOSEUP of one of them. It is Bill Cole (Melvyn Douglas), well-dressed, intelligent, attractive looking young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you're wondering what all  this has to do with Mr. Blandings  and his Dream House? Well, I'll tell  you. Jim Blandings is part of the  fabric of this town. Born and raised  right here, he's as typical a New  Yorker as anyone you'll ever meet.  At least he was. (confidentially) And if you want to know the real  story, I guess I'm your boy. Cole's  my name, Bill Cole. I'm Jim's lawyer  and quote, best friend, unquote.  Jim's one of those bright young men  from Yale. Advertising business,  lovely wife, two fine kids, makes  almost fifteen thousand a year. Want  to know why? Just look up there.

dialogues.speaker: A BILLBOARD
dialogues.text: A billboard -- against a white background is a large ham. large letters across the ham is printed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And below this in quotes: "WHEN YOU'VE GOT THE WHIM, SAY 'WHAM!'"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When you've got the whim, say  'Wham!'"... Jim Blandings wrote that  slogan. Seven magic words that shine  like a beacon light for the American  housewife! (impressive; almost  reverently) "When you've got the whim, say  'Wham!'" Jim Blandings' contribution  to the American Scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As CAMERA MOVES UP it and TOWARD a window:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fourteen years Jim and Muriel  had been living in their apartment  over on East Seventy-fourth Street.  It was just another of those wonderful  crisp September mornings and the  Blandings were still asleep. Just  like millions of other people in  good old Manhattan -- New York City --  U.S.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA GOES THROUGH the window and INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim (Cary Grant) and Muriel (Myrna Loy) Blandings are asl in twin beds. The room, not large to begin with, gives us the impressio of being cluttered up and overcrowded because the beds,  oversized chest of drawers, dressing table and chaise lou take up an inordinate amount of space. SOUND of an alarm clock going off. Jim awakens, yawns him into hazy consciousness, gropes about on the night table the clock; it isn't there. He slips out of bed, and rubbi his eyes, blindly moves toward the dresser. The circuitou path, which he accomplishes with sleepy dexterity, entail going around the chaise lounge, just missing the ominousl pointed edge of Muriel's dressing table, deftly stepping  over the low dressing table chair and finally reaching th chest of drawers upon which is the clock. He turns off th alarm and yawningly starts back over the same path. We ge the feeling that Jim makes this sleepy excursion every wa morning of his life. Back at his bed, Jim sits down, and, yawning loudly, grop with his feet for his slippers. Before he can find them,  however, he begins to doze off and slowly tilts back towa the pillow, pulling the covers over him. In a moment he i sound asleep. Muriel's arm automatically stretches out an shakes Jim into consciousness. As he painfully reawakens starts to rise, Muriel's arm disappears. We get the impression that this, too, is a regular part o the Blandings' daily routine. Jim locates his slippers, reaches around for his bathrobe can't find it, stumbles his way over to the closet, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a fairly good-sized closet but it was never inten to be shared by two people, particularly not Jim and Muri Blandings. Assuming that they had started out on even ter it is now obviously Muriel, three-to-one. Her dresses, go slips, seem to obscure his occasional pair of slacks, sui or sports coat. Her shoes neatly line the floor and the s above is loaded to the ceiling with her hat boxes, in an  orderly but somewhat precarious state of balance. Groping blindly for a robe, Jim feels around and pulls on out. As he slips into the arms, we see it's much too smal for him, obviously Muriel's. In disgust he attempts to pu it back. Unable to find a hook he finally jams it in betw two silk dresses which fall to the floor. As he bends dow and gropes for the dresses, he discovers his robe crumple under them on the floor. He drags the robe out and dons i leaving the dresses where they fell. With a guilty look a Muriel he closes the closet door and starts out of the be and into the narrow hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow corridor extending the length of the apartment. it are doors leading to the bathroom, the childrens' room and the foyer. Jim shuffles down the hall. He stops at the closed bathro door, listens, hears the shower, knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim continues down the hall, stops at the closed door of children's room, knocks. No sound. He opens the door and  enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room, crowded and cluttered up with the accoutrem of adolescence. Joan, an eleven-year-old is asleep in one the twin beds. Jim automatically pulls the covers clear o Joan's bed. She awakens, cocks an eye at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she sleepily stretches and prepares to rise, Jim exits into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Jim through the foyer into the living room on through the very small combination dining and breakfas nook and into the compact but tiny kitchen. Gussie, the  colored cook, greets him heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Mr. Blandings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a feeble attempt at  a smile) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie takes a glass of hot water, squeezes in a little l stirs and hands it to Jim who gulps it down, makes a slig face and pats his stomach. Gussie hands Jim a cup of blac coffee and he starts back toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gingerly balancing the cup and saucer, Jim approaches the door to the children's room. With split-second timing, he pauses as the door flies open and Joan, in her bathrobe,  towel in hand, rushes out and past him down the hall. She disappears into the bathroom. Jim carefully proceeds down the hall and, as he reaches the bathroom, deftly steps to the left as the door bursts open and Betsy flies by on th way back to her bedroom. All this is done with a timing a shifting of hips of which Knute Rockne might have been pr Jim continues down the hall, enters the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is still asleep as Jim enters, walks over, nudges  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel awakens, sniffs the fresh coffee, smiles, sits up, takes the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss briefly. Muriel starts to sip the coffee as Jim goes to his chest of drawers. It consists of several rows small drawers above and large drawers below. Jim ruffles  through a couple of small drawers, pulls out a suit of  underwear, continues noisily and with some annoyance to l through the other drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for something, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly) My socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you look in your sock  drawer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with restraint) That's where I found my underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (brightly) Well, try your underwear drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in my underwear drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches in and holds up one of Muriel's silk slips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping coffee) Well, they must be somewhere. (attempt at morning  cheeriness) Socks just don't get up and walk  away by themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strained patience) Muriel, I thought the top two-and-a- half drawers were to be mine! I wish  you'd tell Gussie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The closet! That's where they are.  We put them in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Socks? In the closet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there didn't seem to be any  room in the drawers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's so much of it in the  closet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so Gussie and I decided that from  now on we'll keep them in a basket  on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks a lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides angrily to the closet, opens the door, reaches for the basket and pulls it off the shelf. As he does so, all the hat boxes come tumbling down knocking the basket  from his hand, the socks spilling on the floor. About to  explode, he looks at Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, I do wish you'd make an effort  to be a little less clumsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely containing  himself) I'll try, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at her barely containing himself, and then puts the hats back in the boxes, jams them back on the shelf w they toter precariously. With bated breath he gingerly cl the closet door. Pause. Silence. He picks up a pair of so and walks cautiously toward the hall door. Suddenly there a rumble and crash from inside the closet. Jim exchanges look with Muriel, is about to say something, changes his  mind, exits into the hall. Muriel looks at the closet, si takes another sip of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim opens the door of the bathroom. There is a scream. He quickly closes the door, scowling with annoyance. A momen later the door opens and Joan emerges, wrapping her robe  around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Father, just one morning I wish you'd  knock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her back as she  walks away) 'Morning, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan disappears into her room as Jim enters the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very small with a stall shower. Jim takes off his bathrob yawns, gets on the scale, looks at the dial, shakes his h He takes a deep breath, draws in his stomach, looks down, scowls, shrugs, gets off, moves to the mirror. He examine the thinness of his hair, the condition of his tongue, et Taking his toothbrush he looks down at the tube he is abo to use, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: THE TOOTHPASTE TUBE
dialogues.text: WHAT HE SEES - the toothpaste tube. It has been squeezed the middle, one of Blandings' pet peeves.

dialogues.speaker: JIM METICULOUSLY SMOOTHES OUT THE TUBE
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Jim meticulously smoothes out the tube, roll up the used portion from the bottom. Then placing a small amount on his brush, he caps the tube, and starts vigorou to brush his teeth. As he does so, he attempts with his f hand, to put the tube back in the medicine cabinet which opens.

dialogues.speaker: THE MEDICINE CABINET
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - the medicine cabinet, loaded to the hilt wit medical accumulation of fourteen years of family life.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Jim. As he pushes the tube into the bulging shelf, a bottle of iodine falls out. Jim makes a desperat one-handed catch, still brushing his teeth. As he pushes iodine into the second shelf, a small bottle of pills pop out. Jim catches it, pushes it back into the cabinet. A b of cough medicine falls out. He catches it, tries to put back, finds it won't fit. He looks at the bottle, sniffs contemplates its value, throws it in the wastebasket. He  finishes washing his mouth, admires his teeth, disrobes a steps into the shower, putting on his shower cap. He reac scowls, takes off the cap and turns it upside down, a ful cup of water falling out. He reaches out for a towel, dri the inside of the cap, carefully puts it back on his now hair. Then he turns the water on and at the first warm sp Jim Blandings' life takes a sharp turn for the better. He starts to sing, a robust bathroom baritone version of "Ho On The Range."

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Jim - He stands in front of the washstand lathering his f Over scene we hear Muriel's voice from the shower. She is singing a lusty chorus of "Home On The Range." Jim picks his razor and turns to the mirror. He reacts with annoyan as he discovers it is covered with steam. With weary  resignation he takes a towel and starts to rub off the mi As he clears one section another clouds up. By the time h gets it all reasonably clear he finds that his lather nee freshening. He grimly relathers his face only to find tha the mirror is again clouded up. As he turns with exaspera toward the shower we see Muriel turn off the water, reach for a towel, start to dry herself. The mirror cleared off, Jim relathers, starts to shave. D this, Muriel, having dried herself and donned her robe, c into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for  toothbrush) Excuse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her toothbrush and then opens the cabinet to ge the paste. Jim, automatically following the mirror, has t squeeze around in a desperately contorted position as he  continues shaving.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Muriel. She takes the tube from the cabinet  and, squeezing the tube in the middle, applies the paste her brush.

dialogues.speaker: JIM AND MURIEL
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel - Placing the tube on the washstand, Murie closes the cabinet. Jim, still shaving, moves back to his original position as he follows the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel nods, steps back, starts to brush her teeth. They  both hum "Home On The Range". Her mouth full, Muriel taps Jim on the shoulder. Without stopping his shaving, Jim mo to one side as Muriel rinses her mouth. She examines her  face in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) If you don't mind, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he steps back in front of the mirror, Muriel continues look at her face in the glass, over his shoulder. She dec she needs a little skin lotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she steps in front  of him) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She again opens the cabinet. Jim once more follows the mi around, nicks his face, gives up, stands glaring arms fol Muriel takes the lotion from the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moment, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time. I can spare the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up) Oh... cut yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut myself every morning. I kind  of look forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you get an electric razor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to shave) Don't like them. No close shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ridiculous! Bill Cole's been using  one for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't have my beard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's silly. Bill's beard is just  as tough and coarse and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) I'm not interested in discussing the  grain and texture of Bill Cole's  hair follicles before I've had my  orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to carry on so. I  only said, why don't you get an  electric razor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I prefer the cool, clean  sweep of the tempered steel as it  glides smoothly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop writing advertising copy! Hurry  up, dear, you'll be late for  breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel exits. Jim sighs, turns back to the mirror and wit few deft strokes finishes shaving. As he reaches for the  water faucet, he encounters the tube of toothpaste, squee in the middle. Reacting with annoyance, he meticulously  smoothes it out and rolls it up from the bottom. He opens the cabinet and gingerly places the tube on the top shelf The iodine bottle pops out. He grimly catches it, studies his problem, has a solution. With his right hand he start slowly to close the mirror door. Just before it closes, h slips the bottle into the cabinet with his left hand, qui slamming the mirror door, trapping the bottle. He reacts  masterfully at his triumph, picks up his robe and starts the door. As he reaches it, there is the SOUND of the cab opening and a crash as the bottle obviously hits the  washstand. As Jim winces,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrow and small. The four Blandings are at breakfast, Ji and Muriel each reading his section of the morning paper, Betsy pasting a clipping in her notebook, Joan engrossed a magazine of popular science. As we come in, Gussie, tak off the orange juice, is squeezing by Jim who accordingly and automatically ducks his head as she passes. Jim  uncomfortably turns the newspaper to another page, folds reacts with pained but controlled exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who did this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT NEWSPAPER, a section of which has been cut out. BACK TO SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very matter-of-factly) I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out her hand to Joan, who, automatically, and  without looking up hands her the salt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have repeatedly told you -- (ducking as Gussie  comes back with coffee) -- don't cut up the morning paper  until I've had a chance to look at  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, father. It's necessary  research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the salt back to Joan who automatically passes to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some sarcasm) I suppose this is another of Miss  Stellwagon's so-called Progressive  Projects?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (using salt and handing  it to Jim) Now dear, there just isn't any point  in sending your children to an  expensive school if you're going to  undermine the teacher's authority in  your own dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not undermining anything. I happen  to be in the advertising business  and keeping abreast of the times is  important to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so is your children's education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly is not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up  from her magazine) Bicker, bicker, bicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eat your cornflakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim ducks as Gussie passes back on her way to the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Joan toast) Joan, every time your father and I  have a lively discussion we aren't  necessarily bickering. (to Betsy; solicitously) What is it, dear, another English  composition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking toast from  Joan) Miss Stellwagon has assigned each of  us to take a want ad and write a  human interest theme about it. (to Jim; passing toast  to him) I found one typical of the  disintegration of our present society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking toast, not  looking up from his  paper) I wasn't aware of the fact that our  society was disintegrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't expect you to be, father.  Miss Stellwagon says that middle- class people like us are all too  prone to overlook the pressures and  tensions which befall the less  fortunate members of our community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim puts down the paper, turns to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great restraint) Muriel, I know it's asking a lot,  but just one morning I would like to  sit down and have breakfast without  social significance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picks up his paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, you really might take a little  more interest in your children's  education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) You can't squeeze blood from a turnip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim reacts with painful resignation, folds his arms, puts down the paper, turns slowly to Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. All right. I'll listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up her  scrapbook) It's just twenty-four words. But in  simple eloquence it mirrors a minor  tragedy of our times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Well?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak  grove, apple orchard, trout stream,  hay fields, four barns, seclusion,  superb view, original beams, paved  highway, acreage... (with emotion) Will sacrifice..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't see it, do you, father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Fellow wants to sell a house so  he puts an ad in the paper. What did  you expect him to do, take it to the  United Nations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be more to it than that. (to Betsy) Isn't there, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, mother. What some people  don't see is the whole sordid picture.  A poor, honest farmer, pushed to the  wall by hardship, soil erosion,  mortgages, everybody gobbling,  gobbling, gobbling, until finally,  in desperation, he is "forced to  sell," and stoops to the crass  commercialism of newspaper  advertising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Oh, indeed... crass commercialism...  advertising...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nose in her magazine) Miss Stellwagon says advertising is  a basically parasitic profession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with extreme control) Oh, she does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stellwagon says that advertising  makes people who can't afford it buy  things they don't want with money  they haven't got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (elaborate sarcasm) Perhaps your Miss Stellwagon is right.  Perhaps I ought to get out of this  "basically parasitic profession,"  which at the moment is paying for  her very fancy tuition, those extra  French lessons, her progressive summer  camp and for that matter, the very  braces on your teeth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't discuss money in  front of the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not, they spend enough of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bicker, bicker, bicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim gives her a look and buries himself in his paper, downstairs buzzer rings. Gussie enters, squeezes by Jim w automatically ducks, goes to the phone in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Who? (calls) Miss Blandings, there's a Mr.  Funkhauser wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funkhauser? (remembers) Oh, Mr. Funkhauser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel looks nervously at Jim who is preoccupied, reading his paper. Then she turns back to Gussie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- better ask him to come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Says to come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie hangs up, squeezes by Jim, exits into the kitchen. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Oh -- uh -- darling, Mr. Funkhauser's  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) ...Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember, Bunny Funkhauser, that  clever young interior decorator we  met at the Collins' cocktail party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distastefully) What's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Well, I imagine he's brought the --  uh -- estimates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) ...Estimates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly; to conceal  a feeling of guilt) Darling, you know how long we've  said we've got to do something about  this apartment, and, well, he called  last week, and I had him come over,  and he's got some simply wonderful  ideas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) There couldn't be two Bunny  Funkhausers, could there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, no, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then this is the same clever young  man who's responsible for that zebra- striped monstrosity in the Collins'  living room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That couch is terribly functional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil Collins told me what he paid  for all that function! (angrily) If you think I'm going to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of doorbell ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, please! (changing subject) Children, you'll be late to school.  Run along and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children rise, pick up their school paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stellwagon says that  functionalism in modern furniture --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hustles Betsy and Joan toward the foyer as Jim rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie has just admitted Mr. Funkhauser. He is a tall,  slender, effete-looking, young man. He is loaded down wit sketches, samples of wallpaper, bolts of material. Betsy Joan brush by him on their way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sharp  appraising look) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they rush out and the door closes, Jim and Muriel ente scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Funkhauser. You  remember Mr. Blandings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sweeps by them into the living room, taking over  completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to pardon my bursting in  at this dreary hour -- (puts a sketch on a  chair) -- practically the middle of the  night -- (puts wallpaper against  mantel) -- but I did so want to catch you  in. I've been at it hammer and tongs  all week and I'm just a mess -- (drapes bolt of chintz  over high-backed  chair) -- but then Muriel and I thought we  ought to talk it over with you before  we take the plunge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funkhauser looks briefly for a high object over which to  display his last bolt of chintz, finds none, settles for  Jim's shoulder over which he drapes the cloth, the folds  flowing down in front. As Jim reacts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothing out folds  on the chintz) After all, it's your home, too, and  it should reflect you. You know,  Man's Castle, all that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks down at the chintz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ominously) Muriel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Jim, just wait till you hear. He's  got some wonderful ideas for the  foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's out! All out! Changed the  whole thing! I just couldn't live  with it! I said to myself, "Bunny,  what are the Blandings? How shall we  do them?" And the answer was perfectly  obvious. Very American, very grass  roots, very blueberry pie -- that  sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dark look at Muriel) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funkhauser fingers the material of a drape, disdainfully  removes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now first, let's dig into this living  room of yours, it's really a dreary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly; to Jim) We want this room to be very gay,  dear. Something in bright reds,  yellows and greens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) Red, yellow and green?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come, Mr. Blandings, let's not  run away from color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not running away -- (a lame joke) -- just backing off a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- yes. (brightly) Now as I see our room, it's definitely  Colonial. You know, cobbler's bench,  breakfront, pie cooler, student lamp,  hooked rug. But everything in good  taste. It must not jump out at you  and scream: "Look -- see how antique  I am!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven forbid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, these things take  imagination. You've simply got to be  able to visualize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely, removing  chintz) If you'll forgive me, Mr. Funkhauser,  what I'd like to visualize -- at  this dreary hour -- is how much is  this all going to cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, really, I hesitate to say.  After all -- (indicates) -- by the time this wall is out we  may find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting) This wall is -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. Source of light is from the  east. Obviously if our room is to  have any function at all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to tear out the wall?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear, it's a wonderful notion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visualize three feet of leaded panes,  the rest --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you give me a figure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! Costs aren't what they used to  be, you know, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Materials are impossible, labor has  just run wild --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an overall figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well!... I shouldn't like to be tied  down. But I suppose if you must have  a figure, I'd say -- mm -- (lightly) -- somewhere in the neighborhood of  seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm... Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be seven... thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Muriel, considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) We-ll. That seems fair. (gathering up materials) After all, we're not running away  from color -- (picks up wallpaper) -- and we are tearing out walls -- (picks up sketches) Mr. Funkhauser, do you have a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, we haven't even discussed the  rest of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will, dear. (leads the whole batch  on Funkhauser)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huffy) Well, really, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deftly steering him  toward the door) We'll talk it all out and then we'll  get in touch with Bunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRUCKS with them to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, really, I mean, I was under  the impression we'd come to some  decision today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We-ll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So nice of you to come. (puts Funkhauser's  hat on his head) Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Funkhauser is gone. Jim closes the door, turns ominou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apprehensively) Now darling, you -- you just don't  go to a man like Funkhauser and ask  how much it's going to cost before  you even know what he's going to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that would be too logical! Seven  thousand dollars! Blueberry pie! I  wouldn't put seventy-five cents into  this broken-down rat trap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sentimentally) It's our home, Jim. Betsy was  practically born in this apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does not make it a national  shrine! (vehemently) Seven thousand dollars and not one  word about closets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closets! You wouldn't even let him  get to the bathroom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got that kind of money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you talk, Jim Blandings,  you'd think I was some kind of  congenital idiot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I'm beginning to wonder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) You can just get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a bad idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He angrily jerks open the hall closet door, pulls his hat down from the shelf, several hat boxes, some ski boots an tennis racket tumbling down on his head. Jim jams his hat onto his head, takes a deep breath and storms out, slammi the door. Muriel walks over to the closet, is about to be down and pick up a hatbox when all of her pent-up emotion explode. She kicks the hat box into the closet, slams the door, starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting from the elevator, Jim enters a door marked:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall are various framed copies of Jim's handiwork. Most prominent are advertisements for a meat product call "Wham!" "A Whale of a Ham!" There is ample evidence of th fact that Jim's most successful slogan is: "When you've g the Whim - say 'Wham!'" Jim enters, goes to his desk, sits down, still emotionall upset. He glances at a photograph of Muriel, looks guilti away, then back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to photograph) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His secretary enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly) 'Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see the color copy  from this month's House and Stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a magazine. He looks at it perfunctorily, i about to hand it back when his eye is caught by an ad on back cover.

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTRY
dialogues.text: INSERT THE BACK COVER - A community and extolling life in the country, sponsored by a group of realtors, local cham of commerce etc. Over a pastoral scene of lovely little h checkering a rolling landscape are the words:

dialogues.speaker: SOOT FOR SYLVAN CHARM
dialogues.text: In smaller type:

dialogues.speaker: CHOOSE YOUR OWN COMMUTING TIME HOUSES OLD AND NEW... ACRE
dialogues.text: Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that be all?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Jim - Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up; blankly) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that be all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without answering he turns back to the ad. The CAMERA COM IN for a HEAD CLOSEUP as he studies the ad and on the sou track we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak  grove, apple orchard, trout stream,  hay fields, four barns, original  beams --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he looks up thoughtfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a convertible, the top down. Jim is driving through Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the way it all started.  The ad was enough to convince Jim --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel - They are leaving Manhattan, entering the Merritt Parkway. Muriel, wearing an orchid corsage, looks curiously at Jim. His answering gesture says, "Just wait see." Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- But Muriel was a little tougher.  I guess the corsage did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - They are driving through a  beautiful Connecticut countryside. Mr. Smith, a local rea estate dealer, is of that shrewd Yankee breed which  specializes in the understatement, underselling school of salesmanship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are, two little fish from  New York -- out in the deep deep  waters of Connecticut real estate.  That's Smith, the real estate  salesman. Mighty shrewd cookie in a  quiet sort of way. Never thought  he'd get a bite this quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith looks speculatively at the Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's sizing up the catch. "Mm.  Let's see. Convertible -- orchids --  must be pretty well fixed. Wonder if  they're lookers or buyers?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes a deep breath, looks at Muriel as if to say, "G that air!" Muriel smiles with approval. Jim pats her hand affectionately. Smith reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're buyers. (confidentially) Yes, sir, Smith, looks like you're  finally going to unload the old  Hackett place. Now first thing is  get 'em a little anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim slows down the car as they approach a rather pictures looking old Connecticut farmhouse. He and Muriel react wi approval, look questioningly at Smith. Smith shakes his h "no," as though to say, "Not nearly good enough for you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th-a-a-t's right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel, Mr. Smith - They pass another house. Jim and Muriel appraise it with interest, look at Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith firmly shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - Another house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Smith, give 'em a little  more line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith shakes his head "no".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - The car pulls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're ready to gaff 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Well, folks, there she is -- the old  Hackett Place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings look off, react with interest and approval.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: What they see -- Burrowed into the upward slope of the la is the old Hackett farmhouse. If the roof seems to sway a little and the massive stone chimney to tilt a bit and th overall condition of board and beam to be a trifle unstea charge it up to age, which will be a hundred and seventy  years come next April. However, the overall effect is  definitely one of picturesque rustic beauty. In the back a series of barns and behind them the rolling hills known Bald Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty mighty pretty little acres...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (involuntarily) It's simply charming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's look cautions against her over-enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is, for an old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Of course, you understand, Mr. Smith,  we're just window shopping, so to  speak. Nothing really definite in  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studies house; with  assumed indifference) Mm. Not a bad-looking place, but  it's certainly a lot older than  anything we had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's no spring chicken -- (sagely) -- but that's just what makes her  such a buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him curiously. Smith's attitude is matter-of fact, almost without enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't just old timber, or a  virgin stand oak grove other side of  the trout stream, or a couple of  fruit orchards... You're buying a  piece of American history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested in spite  of himself) You don't say! How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First year she was built, General  Gates stopped right here to water  his horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Oh! Old General Gates -- Civil War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revolutionary War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, that General Gates. Hear  that, honey, General Gates!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with concern) Wouldn't that make the house over a  hundred years old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Hundred and seventy come next April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings exchange a doubtful look which Smith catche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm not trying to sell you  anything -- all I'm saying is that  one of these days someone with a  little vision and imagination's goin'  to come along, and just steal this  place -- (confidentially) and I mean steal it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings, as one, turn to the house with renewed  interest. This is not lost on Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blandings, I know you can look  at that house and just about picture  what a couple of coats of paint and  a little pointing up here and there  can do to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES TO a HEAD CLOSEUP of Jim as he begins to visualize

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place suddenly DISSOLVES i the New Blandings' Place -- Jim's version. It is a lovely country house. Massive. Masculine. Jim, in jodhpurs, twee coat, pipe and accompanied by two large Irish Setters, is proudly surveying his property. He nonchalantly holds a s beautiful shotgun in the most precisely correct position. CLOSE SHOT - JIM'S FACE. CLOSE SHOT - Jim's face. His lips don't move but we hear voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. Wonder what he meant by "steal?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I guess I don't have to tell  you, Mrs. Blandings, what a woman's  touch could do to a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES to a HEAD CLOSEUP of Muriel as she starts to visualize.

dialogues.speaker: THE OLD HACKETT PLACE
dialogues.text: WHAT SHE SEES - The Old Hackett Place DISSOLVES into a da feminine cottage with criss-cross curtains at the window a lovely little white rail fence enclosing "her garden."  Muriel, in delightful gingham, is in the garden, admiring her latest triumph - the largest rose ever grown in Lansd County. CLOSE SHOT - MURIEL'S FACE. CLOSE SHOT - Muriel's face. Her face is soft. Her lips do move but we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a nice old house. It just needs  someone to love it, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, you've certainly got to  visualize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES to a HEAD CLOSEUP of Smith as he, too, begin to visualize. WHAT HE SEES - THE OLD HACKETT PLACE. WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place. Suddenly SUPERIMPOS over it in large figures is:

dialogues.speaker: SMITH LOOKS AT HIM AND MURIEL
dialogues.text: GROUP SHOT - Smith looks at Him and Muriel who are lookin at the house with unabashed affection. Jim's arm goes ten around Muriel's waist. Smith looks back at the house. WHAT HE SEES - THE OLD HACKETT PLACE. WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place. The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is quickly replaced by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Shall we go up and take a look at  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little too casual) Well -- I -- suppose as long as we're  here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) I guess it doesn't hurt to take a  look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Smith precedes them up the path toward the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) It does have possibilities. Do you  think we can get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Like taking candy from a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Now don't lose your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Shh. Just keep quiet and let me handle  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Smith, what kind of a price  is the owner asking for this old  place?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE OLD HACKETT PLACE
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel precede Smith as they exit from the house. Jim and Muriel carry on a sotto voce conversation, Smith  looks off with some concern in the direction of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful, Jim! That master  bedroom with those two closets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funkhauser could do wonders with  this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Funkhauser will have nothing to do  with this house! Shh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith's face suddenly brightens as a weatherbeaten old ca appears, turns up the driveway, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Hi, George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Eph! (to the Blandings;  feigned surprise) What do you know, it's Eph Hackett,  owner of the place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Well, you don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eph Hackett gets out of the car, saunters over. Hackett i middle-aged, rural-looking, taciturn New Englander

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eph, this is Mr. and Mrs. Blandings --  from New York City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly have a lovely place  here, Mr. Hackett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly) Ye-ap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Mr. Hackett, we've just been talking  to Smith here about -- uh -- taking  the old place off your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hackett exchanges the briefest of looks with Smith who al imperceptibly shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Ain't for sale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Blandings react with dismay:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Why don't you folks just go out in  back and take a look at the orchard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives them a wink which says, "Just leave it to me." T Blandings exchange a look, turn and walk off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'm I doin', George?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice timin', Eph. Think we got  something here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They the same people you showed it  to in nineteen-thirty-eight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were lookers -- this is the  real thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they got five thousand dollars on  'em. don't let 'em get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They already offered ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly) Y'don't say... What's my asking price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mite stiff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got 'em measured. (mellower) They're gonna take the place for -- (turns, looks back at  house) eleven thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it eleven thousand five hundred  fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odd kind of figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might as well take the commission  out of them instead of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Smith raises a knowing eyebrow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel and the two children are having breakfast. Jim ent in high spirits. During this scene we repeat the business passing, etc. used in the previous breakfast scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing gaily to  "Home On The Range") "Home, home in Connecticut With a  closet to hang up your petticut..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he seats himself) ...Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going on, as he places  his napkin in his  lap) "No hustle or fuss No Fifth Avenue  bus --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just wondering, dear. Ten  thousand dollars is such an awful  lot to offer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks suspiciously at her, at the children, then back her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is, for two people who don't  know anything at all about real  estate, or anything... (Jim's look darkens) I mean, don't you think perhaps we  should have asked someone's  professional advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... say... a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Bill knows about these things  and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, for once in my life I'm going  to make one small decision, on my  own, without the legalistic  machinations of Mr. Bill Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems very peculiar that when  your very best friend happens to be  one of the very cleverest young  lawyers in New York City --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, I don't want to hear another  word about Bill Cole! (turns to children) Well, did your mother tell you about  the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Stellwagon says the current  craze for modernizing old farmhouses  is a form of totem worship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great restraint) Did it ever occur to you two that  there may be some remote, intangible  subjects upon which your Miss Irma  Stellwagon is not the final authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we buy a Solaxion house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know it's just barely  conceivable -- What kind of a house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solaxion. It's built on a mast like  a tent and it revolves with the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it... revolves... with the sun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who lives next door -- Buck Rogers?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only practical way to live.  When a new model comes out you trade  the old one in like a used car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plaintively) Muriel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, you haven't even seen this  house yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I'd like a Crane Mobile  home. It comes all folded up and all  you do is plug it in for electricity  and water and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a minute! (to Muriel) What kind of children are these? (to girls) Do you want to spend the rest of  your lives in chromium tents and  portable merry-go-rounds? This house  was built before our country became  a nation. It has dignity. It's --  it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie enters with a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing it to Jim) Special delivery, Mr. Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with suppressed;  excitement) From Smith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he eagerly opens it and reads, his face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "I have conveyed your offer of ten  thousand dollars to Mr. Hackett and  am sorry to say he is not interested.  However, I feel..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. Maybe we should have gone  a few dollars higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stoutly) He's bluffing. Simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For ten thousand dollars we could  get a Rockford Trailer and a Zamboni  Power Unit. It's kitchen, bathroom  and air conditioning all rolled up  into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gives her a weary look, turns to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Muriel, I'll let him push me to ten  thousand, two hundred, but not a  penny more!

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S COST CHART
dialogues.text: INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - Rising diagonally and bisecting the chart is a line graduated in scale starting at $5000 running up to around $17,000. Resting on the line at exac $10,000 is a miniature of the old house. Fluttering acros the scene from left to right is a letter from Smith on th stationery of the Lansdale Realty Co. As we see the letter and hear the voice of Smith, miniatu figures of Smith and Hackett appear at the lower side of house. Their shoulders start pushing the house up the  graduated scale. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Mr. Blandings: While your offer  of ten thousand two hundred is still  not acceptable to Ephemus Hackett -- "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter on Danton & Bascomb's stationery flutters ac the screen from right to left. A miniature figure of Jim  appears above the house, desperately pushing it back. Ove this, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Mr. Smith: You may inform Mr.  Hackett that the very highest I could  possibly go --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a succession of letters flutter across the screen, fir from left to right and then from right to left, and the h is jockeyed back and forth, they are punctuated with the  following lines:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Friend Blandings --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My dear Friend Smith --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Blandings --!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Smith - !"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout this Smith's voice remains bland and unperturb while Jim's has the desperate, frenetic quality of a man  being slowly pushed to the wall. The Special Effect concludes with the house finally and f at rest on the preordained $11,550. As the antagonists on both sides of the house relax, Smith reaches around in fr of the house and shakes hands with Jim. It's a deal! About halfway through when the going gets tough, Jim beck Muriel to help in the losing fight. As they now embrace,  Smith and Hackett shake hands in mutual congratulation.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Door - on it is printed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A successful lawyer's office, the walls crowded with leat bound books. Jim and Muriel are seated facing the large d behind which sits Bill Cole. Bill finishes reading a seri of papers, the sum total of correspondence between Jim an Mr. Smith. He sets down the papers, leans back thoughtful Jim and Muriel look at him with nervous but eager  anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too sure) What do you think, Bill? Steal, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) It certainly is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks triumphantly at Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps "steal" is an understatement --  "swindle" might be a little more  appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pride) Well, it wasn't much, Bill. I just  saw a good thing and I -- (take) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you get a little tight  you weep on my shoulder about the  advertising business and how it forces  a sensitive soul like yourself to  make a living by bamboozling the  American public. (picks up Smith's  correspondence) I would say that a small part of  this victimized group has now  redressed the balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You've been taken to the cleaners  and you don't even know your pants  are off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear, I told you. I said we should  call Bill --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Muriel! (to Bill; challengingly) All right, just what's wrong with  this deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First time around you offered ten  thousand dollars for fifty acres,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's two hundred dollars an acre.  I know that part of Connecticut and  one hundred dollars an acre is  standard top-gouge price to city  slickers. When the natives sell to  each other it's around forty or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty dollars an acre!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's entitled to a fair profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not two hundred and eighty-four  percent. (indicates papers) And besides, you're not getting fifty  acres, you're only getting thirty- five, more or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does it say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up letter) I refer to a rather obscure post- script on the back of the second  letter from Friend Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the letter to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Incidentally, Mr. Hackett has been  a little over-optimistic about the  acreage. It will probably survey  somewhere in the neighborhood of  thirty-five acres, more or less, but  I feel sure..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the defensive) All right, so it's thirty-five! What's  the difference? Do you know how many  tennis courts you can get on thirty- five acres?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not spending eleven thousand  five hundred dollars for tennis  courts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very businesslike) That's precisely the point. We're  going to write this Hackett a strong  letter and tell him he can either  kick in with those fifteen acres,  reduce the price, or find another  sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising emotion) We'll do no such thing! I'm not going  to queer this deal over fifteen broken- down acres!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill) We were just going window shopping  and so far it's cost us eleven  thousand five hundred dollars and  they even made us pay the commission!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean extortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim turns on Bill and is about to answer him explosive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I wonder if we could get another two  year lease on the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heatedly) Now wait a minute! You can't measure  everything on a slide rule. This  house has certain intangibles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what, for instance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like antique value, for instance! It  just so happens that General Gates  stopped right there, at that very  house, to water his horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if General Grant dropped  in for a scotch and soda -- you're  still getting rocked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a different war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Bill's absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling to contain  himself; quietly) Let me explain something. To both of  you. For fifteen years I've been  cooped up in a four room cracker  box! Just getting shaved in the  morning entitles a man to the  Congressional Medal for bravery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't make this a good buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill -- Muriel and I have found what  I am not ashamed to call our Dream  House. It's like a fine painting.  You buy it with your heart, not your  head. You don't ask, how much was  the canvas, how much was the paint?  You look at it and you say, "It's  beautiful... I want it," and if it  costs a few pennies more you pay it --  and gladly -- because you love it  and you can't measure the things you  love in dollars and cents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel looks at Jim, impressed, her face softening with  compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionally spent) Well -- that's how I feel about this  place. And when I sign those papers  Saturday, I can look the world in  the face and say, "It's mine! My  house! My home! My thirty-five acres!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over; moved,  touched) Our house. Our home. Our thirty-five  acres...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tenderly kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...more or less...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Jim's reaction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comprehensive Shot showing village green of a small, typi quaint New England town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Judge Quarles is reading from the title deed, the  proceedings almost over. Jim stands in front of the bench flanked by Muriel and Bill. Mr. Smith and Hackett are the only other people present. As the Judge drones on, Jim an Muriel exchange a smile. Jim squeezes her hand intimately

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "...thence along said stonewall fence  forming the East boundary of said  Lansdale Road, N 20 27' E, 21.84  feet to the end of said stonewall  fence, thence along a wire fence, N  16 31' W, 78.66 feet to a dead twenty- inch chestnut tree, thence westward  to said stonewall fence, to a total  of thirty-one and a half acres --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting) What was that? How many acres?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Quarles looks up impatiently at the interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (precisely) Thirty-one and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hackett) I was under the impression your  property was thirty-five acres, Mr.  Hackett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is... more or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill looks significantly at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mr. Blandings, when you  signed the purchase agreement it was  subject to traced map attached.  Surveyed to an even thirty-one and a  half acres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim turns to Bill for affirmation. Bill soberly nods his  head, "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing, Your Honor, just a few  less tennis courts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gives Bill a sour look as the Judge continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with ministerial  resonance) "...to have and to hold to him, the  said Grantee, his heirs and assigns  to his and their own proper use and  benefit forever."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, and as a shaft of sunlight hits them, a beat look comes across the faces of Jim and Muriel. For a mome it has become their wedding day. After a momentary pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very businesslike) Subject to a six thousand dollar  mortgage held by Ephemus Whittaker  Hackett...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Blandings are startled back to grim reality:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - The Blandings' car. The Blandings and Bill Co driving along. They approach a fork in the road which lea to a very old covered New England bridge. On the bridge i sign which reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pause, turn, go through the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they drive through the dark interior of the bridge the is an appropriate rattling and rumbling of the ancient  timbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another fork in the road. Muriel points to the r to the right. Jim shakes his head, points to the road to left. Muriel points to the right. Jim emphatically shakes his head, puts the car in gear, drives off on the road to the left.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - the car. It goes up to the top of a hill, sto starts up, disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car approaches, the CAMERA discloses it is back at the same covered bridge. The car stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim reacts with annoyance, mops his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Congress ought to pass a law. When a  man buys a house in Lansdale County  there's a prize -- he gets ten percent  off if he can find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim backs up and, over Muriel's protestation that they go right, turns the car left.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - the car. It drives up an empty road, disappea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car approaches, the CAMERA reveals it is again bac at the old covered bridge. The sign still reads: "SHRUNK  MILLS - 2 Mi."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel look at each other with disgust and  resignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the world are "Shrunk Mills?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are probably mills that have  shrunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you certainly aren't much of a  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Look -- you really want to find that  house of yours -- it's no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just pretend you're one of General  Gates' horses and you're thirsty...  Now where would you go for a drink  of water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at him darkly, drives through the bridge, turns right, as Muriel looks slightly triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE OLD HACKETT PLACE
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel and Bill stand a little distance from the hou looking at it. A vast lilac spreads across it. The Blandi are in quiet rapture, and it is Bill who speaks first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frank and open) Well, I must admit it's a very  beautiful thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (misty) The house and the lilac are just the  same age, Bill; if the lilac can  live and be so old, so can the house.  It just needs someone to love it,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three shingles slide from the roof. As Jim and Muriel rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing there are two of  you -- one to love it and one to  hold it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim gives him a look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd your engineer say when he  checked over the foundation and that  roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who needs engineers? This isn't a  train, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw it move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This house has been standing since  the second year of the Continental  Congress. You take one look at it  and shingles start to fall off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if on cue, a few more shingles slide off the roof, nea hitting Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solicitously) Look -- let me do you a favor. I've  got a client, crackerjack structural  engineer, Joe Apollonio; he  practically built the George  Washington Bridge single-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, but we're not building  a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the follow who advised the  Government not to raise the Normandie --  they didn't listen to him, cost them  five million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my word, if I were raising  the Normandie, I wouldn't make a  move without Apollonio. (indicates door) Now would you like to come inside  and look around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a skeptical look at  the roof) No thanks, I'll just stay out in the  car and listen to "Life Can Be  Beautiful."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim opens the door and disappears, there is a crash,  followed by a series of other crashes. Muriel looks in, t back to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better contact Mr.  Apollonio.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE OLD HACKETT PLACE
dialogues.text: Near the front entrance. After a moment, the door opens, the Blandings and Mr. Apollonio emerge. Jim, limping, is  aided and abetted by a cane. Apollonio is a stolid, New Y construction man, replete with derby, blue serge suit, an cigar. A short rule sticks out of a back pocket. As they  emerge, the Blandings are hopefully enthusiastic; Apollon is thoughtfully noncommittal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has charm, hasn't it, Mr.  Apollonio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through his cigar) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, any small changes would  have to conform with the character  of the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through his cigar) Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet still be functional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apollonio casually walks over to the corner of the house, kicks an exposed beam. It crumbles, apparently rotted by  termites. Two shingles fall off. The Blandings watch him  anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing upward;  oblivious) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he thoughtfully rubs his chin, Jim, followed by Muriel limps his way over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, what's your professional  opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apollonio looks at the Blandings, at the house, then back the Blandings. He takes the cigar from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tear it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) Tear it down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your chimney was shot and your  sills was okay, I'd say go ahead,  fix her up. If your sills was shot  and your chimney was okay, again I'd  say go ahead, fix her up. But your  sills are shot and your chimney is  shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this speech Apollonio picks up a wooden frame, squ it with a pocket square, levels it on a fence, and looks  through it at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beckoning) Take a look at the way she sags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings step over, look through the frame. WHAT THEY SEE. What they see. Outlined against the frame, the house slan sagging perceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT as the Blandings react with some dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I say don't throw good money after  bad -- tear it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his hat, walks out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Bill Cole and his experts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Darling, we'll get our own experts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings have just finished surveying the house with Mr. Simpson, another expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so they got their own experts.  Mr. Simpson said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tear it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings have just finished examining the house with Mr. Murphy, another expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, Mr. Murphy said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better tear it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings smile feebly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings and Jones, another expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then just to be a wee bit  different, Mr. Jones said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly; deep bass  voiced) Tear it down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blandings are now considerably shaken.

dialogues.speaker: A SHINGLE.
dialogues.text: A shingle. It reads in neat, conservative lettering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's how our friend, Mr. Simms,  came into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel, Simms. The room is in quiet, good taste, a  flagstone fireplace, modern steel casement windows, windo seats, etc. The walls are crammed with books and photogra of Simms' handiwork. There are a couple of gold medal  citations of his work conspicuously spaced around the roo Simms is a tweedy, pipe-smoking, conservative New England a distinguished-looking local architect. He puffs thought on his pipe as he looks at a photograph of the old Hacket place, an exact duplicate of the shot we saw through the  window frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you could fix up that old  house. You can fix up any structure  that's still standing. The sills and  floors couldn't be worse, I grant  you, and I guess you'd have to jack  up that west corner at least three  feet to make it level. Need new  chimney. New roof. Complete new  plumbing. (sigh) Too bad you didn't buy it ten years  ago. Could have fixed it up in jig  time then, and it would have made  some sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously nibbling  at his nails) Uh-huh... mm-hmmm... uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fact is, before you're through, it  would be less expensive to tear the  old place down and build a new one,  same size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm. New house... (as the notion sinks  in, becomes attractive) New house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simms, with  pleasant incredulity) You mean... for the same money... we  could build a brand new house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly wouldn't cost any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) Hm... New house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and looks thoughtfully at Muriel who raises an  interested eyebrow. Then, to Simms:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Just... what sort of thing do you  have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
