dialogues.text: Well, I imagine the type of house  you'd want would be something in  quiet good taste, two story, frame  and brick veneer construction --  modern, but of course fitting in  with the architectural traditions of  the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -- What do you think, Muriel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd like to see a basic  floor plan -- (reaches into file  behind him) -- something like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms places the basic floor plan on the desk before him, the Blandings moving around, flanking him. They examine t plan with interest. WHAT THEY SEE -- THE PLAN. What they see -- the plan. A simple master plan of a two  story house, the names of the various rooms indicated. As talks, we see Simms' hand, holding a pencil, point out th various rooms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First floor. Living room, study,  dining room, kitchen, service porch,  maid's room -- upstairs three family  bedrooms with two adjoining baths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT. The Blandings praise the plan with the  uncompromising expertness of two people who have never se such a plan before in their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very nice, I'm sure, but -- uh --  well -- doesn't it seem just a little  bit conventional?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Simms, if we were going to build  a house we want it -- well, you know --  just a little bit different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's heard all this  before) Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, for instance -- (takes Simms' pencil)

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING BOARD.
dialogues.text: THE DRAWING BOARD. Jim's pencil traces as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- here in the study if we could  just push out this wall a little --  and put in a built-in bar we could --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, dear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand takes the pencil from his, starts to trace as sh talks. Jim's fingers drum with the beginnings of impatien

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These bedrooms. They do seem rather  small. And, of course we'd have to  have a little dressing room -- and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she draws it in, Jim's hand takes the pencil. Muriel's fingers drum nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And closets, Simms, lots of closets. (traces them in) If there's one thing this family  needs, it's closets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his hand reaches  for the pencil) If I might make a suggestion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Muriel's hand reaches the pencil first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she draws them in) And bathrooms, Mr. Simms. Each bedroom  must have at least one bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that would be four bathrooms,  Mrs. Blandings -- (his hand reaches for  the pencil) I think I'd better point out to you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's hand reaches the pencil before Simms. Now Simms' fi and Muriel's drum in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. Do you think -- (tracing) we might manage a little playroom in  the basement, nothing tremendous,  you know, something like this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his hand reaches  for the pencil;  cautiously) Well, it's always possible, but at  the moment our fundamental problem --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Muriel's hand has the pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she traces) And I've always wanted a little sewing  room upstairs -- (Jim's and Simms'  fingers drum  impatiently) You know, a little utility room where  I can be alone, and sew, or sulk, or  on a rainy afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his hand takes  pencil) Pardon me, dear. On that playroom,  Simms, not too small. You know, plenty  of room for ping-pong, darts, nice  big poker table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as his hand reaches  for another pencil) If you don't mind, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Muriel has reached the pencil first. As she and Jim s simultaneously and the scene begins to DISSOLVE, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And off the kitchen, I'd like a  little flower sink just to putter  around in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And a terrace off the study, with  an owning and little outdoor  fireplace...

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING BOARD
dialogues.text: THE DRAWING BOARD - The original plans are lost in a maze the Blandings' extensions, alterations and additions.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE ARE SOMEWHAT EXHAUSTED
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT - The three are somewhat exhausted, silently  looking at the plans. Simms wearily runs his hand through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delicately) We-ll... let's just see what we have  here. In the first place --

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING BOARD
dialogues.text: THE DRAWING BOARD - Simms' pencil indicates as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm afraid you've got the upstairs  about twice as big as the downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all those bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not, it's all those closets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By extending this breakfast room  you've eliminated the possibility of  any stairs going to the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you can just shove those stairs  in anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently; almost  paternally) And, Mrs. Blandings, on that sewing  room, the way you have it now, the  chimney stack would come up right  through the middle of the room,  leaving you with something in the  shape of a square doughnut. (tactfully) Which, of course, might be very warm  in winter, but otherwise of doubtful  utility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always move the chimney  somewhere else, couldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We-ll... (rising; resigned to  his fate but tactful) Look, I think I know just about what  you two have in mind. Why don't I go  ahead with some preliminary plans  and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hearty) You do that, Simms, but remember,  we've got to hold it down to ten  thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (candid) That, I can tell you right now, is  impossible. Even with a considerable  trimming of the things you've  indicated, I don't see how we can  bring it in for less than twelve or  twelve-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve-five! (looks at Muriel;  then) Well, I guess we're not going to  quibble about a few pennies one way  or the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't resist) No, you'll find Mr. Blandings never  quibbles about pennies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And -- uh -- have you any notions  about how you'd like the old place  taken down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a rueful joke) Why don't we just blow on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wry smile) There's a good local house wrecker.  I'll have him contact you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim expansively puts his arm around Simms' shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. You just shoot ahead with those  plans, and remember, try to keep it  down to ten, ten-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) Well -- we'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Blandings walk to the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one good thing about getting  that old relic down. Those original  beams and everything -- this time  somebody pays us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go out the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Hackett house matted to show winter sky, bare trees. the f.g. bare ground with patches of snow. Eph Hackett is standing with one of the wreckers. In the  b.g. we see the frame of the old house, firmly intact, th chimney still standing within it. There are mountains of  shingles, splintered boards and other rubbish, piled abou The piles are reasonably neat and sorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them beams is worth money. You payin'  him, or he payin' you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's payin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating) A thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squawked, but he paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Hmm. I guess maybe I got a little  somethin' comin' too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts out of scene:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys, let her go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tractors attached to chains and cables start to pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINIATURE SHOT - What is left of the house collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel are standing there, having watched the  demolition. As the dust settles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh) Well, so far it's cost us thirteen  thousand, three hundred and twenty- nine dollars and forty-five cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've got the nicest vacant lot  in the state of Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange a look of mixed emotions.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMS' NEW PRELIMINARY PLANS
dialogues.text: INSERT SIMMS' NEW PRELIMINARY PLANS - Fresh and workmanli a few small sections crossed out where cuts have been  indicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Something will have to give somewhere,  that I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to disclose:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel and Simms are going over the preliminary plan Betsy and Joan are present, Betsy reading the Lansdale Bl and Joan reading a science book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible. I don't see how we  can cut another inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, you heard Simms. As the house  stands now it's over fifteen thousand  dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it just doesn't seem possible -- (afterthought) for a house with such small rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) Mrs. Blandings, I've already  explained. It's not only the size of  the rooms so much as it is the number.  You see, our primary problem is one  of cubage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, dear, cubage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- (sorry he got into it) just a figure of speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little irritably) Cubage. It's just the number of cubic  feet that -- (lost, lamely) -- go into a cubic foot. Go on, Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting plans) Now is it absolutely essential for  each of your daughters to have her  own room with two closets and a  separate bath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look at the girls;  clearing his throat) Yes. You see, er, my daughters are,  er, approaching womanhood, and, er --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brief look at the  girls) I hadn't realized they were  approaching it quite so fast. (to Jim) Perhaps what you need is not so much  a house as a series of little  bungalows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm. (examining plans) What about that silly flower sink?  We could eliminate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or that sewing room upstairs, that's  certainly a waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're going to eliminate anything,  we'll lose that ridiculous play room  in the basement with that great big  poker table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I've got to have some  relaxation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got thirty-one and a half acres.  Go out in the back and do a little  gardening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, and get poison ivy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with dogged patience) If I may interrupt, I'd like to  suggest that none of these are really  major eliminations. Now if we could  do with one less bathroom on the  second floor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. We couldn't possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Blandings, a simple bathroom,  eight by ten by eight with grade A  fixtures will cost around thirteen  hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I refuse to endanger the health of  my children in a house with less  than four bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For thirteen hundred dollars they  can live in a house with three  bathrooms and rough it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, perhaps the most practical  thing would be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look, we're in the Lansdale paper! (reading) "Historical Society Blasts Vandalism!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, Simms explained to you. We've  just got to cut, cut -- (reacts) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Censure Vote Passed re Destruction  of Famed Hackett Edifice."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, isn't that just too bad! Let  me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the paper, scans it, suddenly bursts into laught

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Prutty. Mrs. Bildad Prutty. Get a  load of this! (reads) "The semi-monthly meeting of the  Lansdale Historical Society was turned  into an uproar last night when its  president, Mrs. Bildad Prutty" --  How do you like that, Bildad Prutty? --  "reported the total demolition by  its New York buyer of the historic  old Hackett house." (laughs) Bildad Prutty! Muriel, I've got to  send this to the New Yorker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Read on, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scans paper) "Mrs. Prutty," -- Bildad, that is --  "reminded her audience that several  years ago the Society started to  raise a fund to purchase and restore  the old house to its original  condition." (looks up, laughs  scornfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read on, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to paper) "The project fell through by being  seven hundred dollars short of the  sum of twenty-six hundred dollars..." (Jim slows down as  the following  registers) "...which Ephemus Hackett testified  was the lowest reasonable price he  could accept as --"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The paper drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) ...Twenty-six hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did we pay, father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven-five, with the commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, isn't it time for those  children to be in bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now girls, I don't want to tell you  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CAMERA FOLLOWS Muriel to the door, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six hundred dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comfortingly) I wouldn't be too concerned about  Mrs. Prutty and her committee. After  all, it's your property and if you  want to tear it down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel opens the door, admits an excited Bill Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Why, Bill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briefly) Hello, Muriel. (he strides past her  waving a telegram;  to Jim) Well, you've done it again'. Once,  just once, why don't you come to me  and find out if it's all right, if  it's legal, before you go barging  off and run yourself smack into  another jam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's eating you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him; to  Simms) And I must say, Simms, I hold you  equally responsible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simms; indicating  Jim) Did you let this idiot tear down  that house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he did? What of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill) Reconstruction was unsound and totally  impractical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quite agree. But you're dealing  with a man who doesn't think before  he acts, who goes off half-cocked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him; to  Simms) You're an architect! You must have  been aware of the legality involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What legality?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simms) You knew there was a mortgage on  that house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assumed as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? What are you talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him; to  Simms) And you know the requirements in  regard to a mortgage where there's  demolition intended!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. But since you were his  lawyer, I naturally assumed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a man like this you can't assume  anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Just one minute! I am entitled to  know what I did! This is America! A  man's guilty until he's proven  innocent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the other way around, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, I've had a very trying day.  Would you mind telling me in clear,  concise English just what crime I've  committed -- and why?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with weary resignation) In clear, concise English, you tore  down a house on which another man  holds a mortgage without first getting  his written permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -- I did?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in such case, the mortgagee can  demand the full payment of said  mortgage upon demand -- (waves telegram) and Mr. Ephemus Hackett so demands!  Six thousand clams! And he wants  them now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) Now?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got ten days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gulps. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For six thousand dollars we could  have had a Solaxion house and a Crane  Mobile home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (herding the kids  toward the door) Girls, say your good nights and off  to bed without another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Good night, Mr. Simms. Uncle Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting) Miss Stellwagon says the problems of  the parents should be the problems  of the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shooing them out) You keep that in mind, dear. It'll  help prepare you for motherhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children exit. An embarrassed pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we'd better let the plans go  for the time being and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) No, Simms, I'll work this out. You  go ahead with your final plans and  let's see some estimates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll just forget about that  extra bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preparing to leave) Very well. You'll hear from me as  soon as possible. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good nights are exchanged. Muriel takes Simms out of scen toward the door. CAMERA HOLDS on Bill and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defeated) Six thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill looks at Jim with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you do for collateral on  your building loan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, turn in my insurance  policies or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming into scene) Now, Jim, you can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if something should happen? You  can't leave the children unprotected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat irritably) I'm not dead yet! And if I die,  there's plenty left to take care of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you cash in your policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim reacts with painful resignation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it won't be necessary. I'll  see the boys at the bank. Maybe you  can put up your insurance as  collateral. If necessary, I'll sign  a personal note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Thanks, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (paternally) And Jim, do me a little favor. The  next time you're going to do anything,  or say anything, or buy anything,  think it over very carefully, and  when you're sure you're right --  forget the whole thing. Good night,  Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to Muriel and kisses her on the cheek. Jim sees i is annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Muriel and Bill to the door. He exits. Mur comes back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a wonderful friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly) What's with this kissing all of a  sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because a man is helpful in a  business way, it doesn't give him  extra-curricular privileges with my  wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fine thing to say about a  friend of fifteen years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testy) Well, I don't like it. Every time he  goes out of this house, he shakes my  hand and he kisses you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Would you prefer it the other way  around?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) Well, I don't like it, that's all!  Why is he always hanging around? Why  doesn't he ever get married -- or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (assumed innocence) Because he can't find another girl  as sweet and pretty and wholesome as  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- it -- it doesn't look right.  There are limits to friendship and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel comes over, puts a sympathetic arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, let's not be silly about  this. It's not Bill, it's the house  you're upset about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh) I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's worth all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, darling. We're not just  building a house -- it's a home. A  home for ourselves -- and our children --  and maybe our children's children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whimsically) It's getting awfully crowded with  only three bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other, smile and kiss intimately, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel are watching Simms, who has just taken a  typewritten sheet from his files. Simms looks at the shee turns to them a little apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- here are the estimates. Before  you look at them, I think I'd better  explain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother, Simms. (takes the sheet) I'm getting to be an old hand at  this sort of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is halfway into his chair as his eye catches the firs bid. There is a sharp MUSICAL EFFECT as Jim bounces out o his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumping H. Mahogany --!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA GOES IN for a CLOSE SHOT of the column of  estimates. As the CAMERA IRISES DOWN ON each sum, there i dissonant MUSICAL EFFECT. Antonio Doloroso, Builders  $32,117.00 Caries & Plumline  $30,500.00 Julius Akimbo & Co.  $28,575.00 Zach, Tophet & Payne  $24,250.00 John Retch & Son  $21,000.00

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT - Jim, Muriel, and Simms. Muriel has read the  column over Jim's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now obviously these bids are way out  of line, that is, all except John  Retch and Son at twenty-one thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting) Twenty-one thousand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with some judicious cutting, I  think we can pare that down to  eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've only asked for the barest  necessities --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, with all the extras you two  have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. (hands estimates to  Simms) If you'll just send us a bill for  your services, I'll see that it's  taken care of. (takes Muriel's hand  and starts for door) Now, if you'll excuse us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going out to get my head  examined! Then, if I don't jump off  the Brooklyn Bridge, I'm going to  find the owner of our building and  sign a twenty-year lease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they are about to exit, they pause as their eyes are c by a drawing on an adjacent drawing board.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: What they see - a beautiful pencil and charcoal drawing o their completed prospective house. Under it, in neat lett is printed: RESIDENCE OF MR. AND MRS. JAMES H. BLANDINGS

dialogues.speaker: JIM, MURIEL, AND SIMMS.
dialogues.text: Jim, Muriel, and Simms. They look at the drawing, then at each other. Jim's face softens. Muriel looks at him  appealingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What's the name of that contractor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT JIM'S COST CHART. The house rests on the diagonal  line at the figure of $13,500. As the miniscule Jim and M watch with apprehension, the small figures of Smith and  Hackett are joined by Simms, John W. Retch, and several s contractors, who put their collective shoulders to the ho and push it past the Blandings and up to $31,000.00

dialogues.speaker: EXCAVATION
dialogues.text: A sign on a sawhorse - it reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over scene is the thunderous dissonance of the various SO that go into preliminary construction. A steam shovel in  action, a bulldozer, the sawing of wood, and intermittent the loud, earth-shaking crash of a well-digger's rig. As the CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see the machines and workmen their various tasks. The scene has all the rustic peace o the invasion of Hollandia. The ANGLE CHANGES, and we see Jim, Muriel, and Bill drive the improvised driveway very close to the scene of activi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel look at their property with unconcealed pr Bill is interested but would like it better if there were less noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting over noise) Well, things are certainly humming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) I said, humming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they get out of the car, there is an unusually loud cr from the well-digger's rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) What's going on over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) That's Mr. Tesander. He's digging  our well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Well? What happened to the trout  stream, with that pure, clear, cold  mountain water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) I decided against it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sudden cessation of the steam shovel and compl silence. Jim, unaware of it, continues to shout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trout stream -- (reacts; quietly) didn't seem practical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't exactly a decision, dear. (to Bill) We discovered the trout stream dries  up in August and the rest of the  year it's polluted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively; groping) Well, anyway, I'd rather have artesian  water. It's healthier. Calcium --  vitamins -- artesian --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) What's wrong with that steam shovel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look off.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE. A CLUSTER OF WORKMEN
dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE. A cluster of workmen have gathered around Zucca, the driver of the steam shovel, who is swearing in voluble but undistinguishable Italian. JIM, MURIEL AND BILL. Jim, Muriel and Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off for the steam shovel, nimbly jumping over a drainage trench. Muriel starts to follow, pauses, unable negotiate the trench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim turns in time to see Bill pick Muriel up and carry he across the trench. As he sets her down:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic; to Jim) Thank you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim frowns, annoyed. They approach the group around the  shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Mr. Zucca?  Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you lika that? Broka my bucket.  Two times this week I broka my bucket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do, strike a boulder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly) Atsa no boulder, atsa ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meansa we gotta blast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blast. Witha dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, dynamite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little annoyed) What do you mean, "What do you mean?"  Mr. Zucca just explained. He's going  to use dynamite and blast until he  gets rid of the rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atsa no rock, atsa ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Mr. Blandings means is -- what  precisely is a ledge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ledge. Lika bigga stone, only a- bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a boulder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, like ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Muriel and Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Like a ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't gotta worry. Only cost  twenty-four cents a cubic foot, plussa  dynamite an'a fuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how far will you have to blast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harda tell. Might be a lilla baby  ledge -- mighta run the whole toppa  the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) At twenty-four cents a foot? Do you  realize what that means?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Meansa we gotta blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zucca walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with quiet resignation) Well, anyway, our house will never  sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) If it does, we can always get Mr.  Apollonio. He raised the Normandie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a crash from the well-digging rig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Come to peaceful Connecticut -- (another crash) Trade city soot for sylvan charm."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) How long does that go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (to Bill) Three weeks now at four dollars and  fifty cents a foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (asserting his  authority) I think I'd better have a little  talk with Mr. Tesander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts off. Muriel and Bill, curious, follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander, a stolid New England well-digger, the soul of  industry and candor, attacks the earth. Jim, followed by  Muriel and Bill, walks into scene, stands by, watching hi After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Mr. Tesander --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motor is making too much noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) Mr. Tesander!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander looks up, shuts off his motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers a moment;  then:) It's comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a nod he turns on his motor, resumes work. Jim excha a look with Muriel and Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no -- I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's drowned out by the motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Mr. Tesander!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander patiently stops his motor, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I meant was -- how far down are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander looks at his equipment, considers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- 'bout a hundred and ninety  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- isn't that pretty deep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks it over; he's  not one for snap  judgments; then:) Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's about to turn on his motor, but Jim detains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think maybe you'd better try  another spot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- well, have you hit anything  yet at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks it over) Hit some limestone yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Bill who shakes his head with mock commisera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And right now it looks like we're  coming into some shale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Muriel for comfort which isn't forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course it might turn out to be  sandstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander shakes his head, "No."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander shakes his head, "No."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't tell. Might be good. Might be  bad. One thing you know -- you got  plenty of shale, sandstone and  limestone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns a little helplessly to Muriel and Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a hot day there's nothing like a  nice cool limestone shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Mr. Tesander, just for the record,  of course, what ever happened to  water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's there, all right. (he smiles, nods,  tips his hat to Muriel) Just got to be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on his motor, goes back to work. Jim, Muriel and Bill start to move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me, this project's getting  a little out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Nothing's getting out of hand at  all. I've made a chart of the whole  operation, and -- (indicates Tesander) with a few minor deviations, I know  exactly what every penny's going to  cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pennies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) And just what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Meansa we gotta blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a loud dynamite blast o.s. As a shower of dirt a rocks cascade down and they run for cover:

dialogues.speaker: JIM'S COST CHART
dialogues.text: INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - Jim stands casually above the h holding the line with one hand. The group pushing from be now consists of Smith, Hackett, Simms, Retch, Tesander, Z and assorted sub-contractors and workmen. As the house mo up a thousand dollars, Jim firmly pushes it back. It now  rests at $33,500.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Mary, the average fellow  who builds a house doesn't know where  he stands from day to day -- but I  do things a little differently. With  a few minor deviations I know exactly  where every penny is going --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. It opens and Bill Cole appe briefcase under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill! Come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering) Just going over the Knapp contracts  with old man Dascomb and I -- uh -- (indicates Mary) Can I talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little concerned) Sure. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obliquely) While I was in there with Dascomb  the conversation kind of got around  to you and -- uh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he didn't say in so many words  that ever since you started with  that house you haven't turned in a  decent piece of copy, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you kind of got the feeling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that if I told you, you'd know  that he knew that you knew that he  knew... that you knew... or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he worrying about? The  deadline's three months off. I've  always --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Mary answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes. Just a minute. (hands phone to Jim) Mrs. Blandings calling from Lensdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Muriel. What? What's that?  Tesander struck water! Say that's  wonderful! (to Bill) We've finally got our well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hand. Jim absently shakes it, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listens at phone) Huh? What's that? (face falls) What do you mean we've got two wells? (listens; then, grimly) I'll be right out. (hangs up, rises) Come on, Bill, we'd better get out  to Lansdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly, as he slips  into his coat) Mary, have you ever seriously  considered building a house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no offense, Mr. Blandings, but  my boy friend says that anybody who  builds a house today is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stick with that boy, he's got a  great future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he and Bill start for the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, Jim, Bill, Simms and Retch stand at the edge look down at the excavation which is partially filled with bub water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you hit a spring, a bubbling  spring right here in our cellar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll have to be diverted before  Retch here can lay his cement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubiously) May take a while. Pumps are over in  Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander walks into scene, looks down at the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk, tsk, tsk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mild sarcasm) Water, Mr. Tesander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At six feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates) And over there, just thirty-two yards  away, you had to go down two hundred  and twenty-seven feet to hit the  same water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you account for that, Mr.  Tesander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander considers a moment, rubs his chin, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We-ll, way it seems to me, Mr.  Blandings, over here the water's  down around six feet and over there  it's -- uh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- down around two hundred and twenty- seven feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim exchanges a weary look with Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL EFFECT
dialogues.text: SPECIAL EFFECT: It consists of a Montage of the following

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (1) The water being pumped out of the excavation. (2) The cement mixer pouring cement into wheelbarrows. (3) The pouring of the cement floor, walls and foundation (4) Planks, shingles and plumbing equipment begin to arri and are strewn about the property. (5) The exterior framing of the house begins to go up. (6) The sheathing is put on. (7) The roof is constructed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's Cost Chart. - With each successive operation, a new workman is added to the already considerable group of peo who are pushing the house inexorably upward, this against the frantic efforts of a slowly weakening Jim Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exterior sheathing is completed and, in the roughest terms, the project begins to resemble a house. Among the  workmen's cars we notice the Blandings' convertible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen hammers, saws, trowels, etc. are heard in other p of the house busily rasping and banging away. Jim and Mur and Bill appear in the doorway before entering the rough  unfinished interior of what will eventually be the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, another closet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This happens to be our dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the dining room, dear, the living  room. (indicates) There's the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then where's the dining room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's that little room off the  hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the breakfast nook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the breakfast nook, it's  the powder room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor -- don't ever invite  me here for a meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two workmen pass by carrying a few long pieces of lumber. The workmen don't see the Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't figure this Blandings at  all. If you gotta build on the  windiest hill in Connecticut, why do  you have to pick the windiest side  of the hill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to workman) You know these New York millionaires --  they're eccentric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The workmen pass from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd like to go outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesture to door) After you, Rockefeller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter the foyer, a carpenter appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Just the man I want to see. Would  you step over here a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) I'll browse around upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bill starts up the stairs, Jim and Muriel follow the  carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing up) On them second floor lintels between  the lally columns, do you want we  should rabbet them or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost) The -- second -- floor -- lallys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second floor lintels, between  the lallys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, the lintels between the  lallys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. From the blueprints you can't  tell. You want they should be  rabbeted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim throws a brief look at Muriel who is regarding him  skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un -- umm. No, I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you're the doctor. (calls) Hey, fellas, you got any of them  rabbeted lintels set, rip 'em out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the sheerest pause there comes a shriek of nails  brutally withdrawn from timber, a loud splintering of woo and then something of the appearance of entrails comes  hurtling down end over end landing with a dusty slap at J feet. The carpenter exits. Muriel gives Jim an accusing l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) It sounded less... expensive to say  no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another loud screech and more "entrails" come  hurtling down, narrowly missing them. Muriel yells in the direction from which they came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From upstairs comes a long, shrill whistle. Instantly all sound of activity ceases and a voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fellas, let's quit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Muriel) Now look what you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Muriel turns with apprehension, eighteen workmen come  trooping down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Look, men, Mrs. Blandings didn't  mean anything. (the workmen regard  him curiously) I mean, there's no point in walking  off a job just because... a woman  makes a silly little remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Saturday, mister. We quit at  twelve o'clock. This ain't a chain  gang, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the workmen exit the Blandings look at each other a li sheepishly, start up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: AS THE BLANDINGS GO UP THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: CRANE SHOT - as the Blandings go up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just sick. From the outside this  house looks like a grain elevator,  and on the inside everything's miles  too small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they reach the second floor landing, we hear, o.s. a s but muffled pounding. They stop as they hear the thumping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That noise -- listen. (again the thumping) It's coming from the closet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush to the closet, open the heavy oak door. Bill is inside, leaning disgustedly against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door blew shut. I got locked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. I had this closet built  especially for myself. The lock opens  from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe for Houdini -- not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bill starts to step out, Jim detains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to it. A child could work  it. Look, I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps inside with Bill, firmly closes the door. A mome pause. The door re-opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (condescendingly) You see, it just takes a little good  old Yankee know-how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dear, it's just possible  the lock worked for you and not for  Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. Even you could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ushers Muriel inside and the door closes on the threes The CAMERA REMAINS on the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, dear, just open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The knob turns, jiggles a little, but the door remains cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't seem to be able to ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let me show you! You just take  the knob and turn it clockwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An efficient clockwise turn of the knob. Pause. An impati doubletwist of the knob. Pause. A more forceful rattling the knob, plus a slight kick. A furious rattling, poundin and kicking. The door remains closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim turns sheepishly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like that good old Yankee  know-how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim turns back to the door, pounds on it, yelling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Somebody let us out of  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Muriel is at the shoulder-high circular frame so glass window. She looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Bill look out.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE - The last of the workmen's cars driving aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Leave a call for seven o'clock. (afterthought) Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gives him a look, turns back to the window, sizing up escape, starts muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could just get over to that  scaffolding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tests the window frame, finds it solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still muttering) Seems a shame but I guess it's the  only way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim picks up a piece of tar paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get panicky, I'll get you out  of here. (hands tar paper to  Bill) Here, hold this over the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bill somewhat skeptically complies, Jim picks up a pie of two-by-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim raises the plank, takes a stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bill) Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim swings; the window shatters. Almost simultaneously th is a click and the door to the closet swings open. As Jim turns with a sense of accomplishment, his face falls as h and the others see that the erratic door has opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) In case of emergency -- break glass.  Come on, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Muriel and Bill precede Jim out of the closet and down the stairs, Jim pauses, speculatively toying with the loc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Funny... always worked before. Huh.  I wonder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel and Bill walking down the stairs. From upstairs co a steady sullen pounding from the interior of the closet. Without a word, they stop, look at each other, turn and w back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel and the children are having breakfast. Jim enters, fairly high spirits, once again improvising to "Home On T Range."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he sits down) "Home, home in Connecticut -- Where  you have to conform to local  traditions, customs, politics and  etiquette..." (picks up his morning  mail, starts to thumb  through it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, do you suppose I could have a  chemistry lab in the basement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied with  mail) Sure, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's awful. Smelling up the  house with those horrible chemicals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Betsy. (to Jim) Dear, I'm going up to the place this  afternoon to see about landscaping.  Bill's driving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) That's nice. (looking up; darkly) What do you mean, Bill's driving  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little annoyed) Why do you always say, "what do you  mean," when you know perfectly well  what I mean and what you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that every time I turn my  back Bill Cole's driving you some  place or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's only being helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed; tears open  a letter) I thought he was a lawyer! Why isn't  he out suing somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bicker, bicker, bicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joan) Another word and you don't get your  laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim suddenly explodes, crumpling a letter he has just rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just see about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) What is it, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring her, he reaches for the phone, starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone; sharply) Mr. William Cole, please. (pause; then with  rising emotion) Hello, Bill? I want you to fight  this thing! I know my rights as a  citizen! They can't get away with  it!... What do you mean, what am I  talking about? The letter, of course.  From the owner of this building.  They want us to move! It's a thirty  day notice! (listens a moment) But that's ridiculous. How can I  move into a house that isn't even  finished?! No windows, no plaster --  or paint, or -- or plumbing! (listens a moment;  then with rising  emotion) Now you listen to me! I have no  intention of moving in thirty days!  This is not legal! I'm going to fight  this thing! And I don't care if it  takes every penny I've got! (listens) Yeah... Yeah... Yeah... All right! (hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expectantly) ...Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) We're moving in thirty days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Muriel's reaction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two moving vans are approaching the bridge. Behind them i the Blandings' convertible. In it are Jim, Muriel and the children. Behind it and attached is a trailer. After a pa over this, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So-came thirty days -- and they moved.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE TO BRIDGE.
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - Entrance to bridge. As the cavalcade pa through we see in the rear of the trailer, jammed among t household effects, Gussie and a very uncomfortable Mr. Bi Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- we moved.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER END OF BRIDGE AND FORK
dialogues.text: The moving vans precede the convertible, make the wrong t Jim stops the convertible at the fork and honks as he  impatiently gestures to the drivers to turn in the opposi direction. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Jim would say it) That's the wrong road! Any fool knows  that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim starts his car up leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moving vans turn up the new gravel driveway. Jim stop his car and they all look off at the house, react with  pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: COMPLETION.
dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE - LONG SHOT - The house is rapidly nearing  completion. A half dozen men are finishing the exterior  painting, planing down doors, etc. In front, a couple of from the nursery are working on the landscaping. For the  first time we, as well as the Blandings, see the property a clean, bright and very attractive new house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there she is, bright and shining --  and just about complete -- the  residence of Mr. and Mrs. James H.  Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING SHOT - Jim and Muriel are visibly affected by the  sight of their Dream House. They exchange a warm intimate smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. The car pulls up, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (efficient scoutmaster) All right! -- Everybody out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody piles out of the car. As Jim and Muriel walk to the house away from us and Bill, Muriel sentimentally rea out, takes Jim's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you can't blame them for feeling  just a little bit proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door, Jim stops, indicates that he'd like to carry Muriel across the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sentimentally) Look -- he wants to carry his wife  across the threshold. Romantic, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN AND BETSY.
dialogues.text: Joan and Betsy. They look on with distinct adolescent  disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooops! I guess I meant "corny."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUP SHOT. Over Muriel's playful protest, Jim starts to  pick her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. Watch that sacroiliac. Fifteen  years since you've done this sort of  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim manages to lift Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! Nice work, Tarzan. Now, let's  see if you can make it into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim carries Muriel over the threshold and into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Go right in. Don't pay  any attention to the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS TO a LOW SHOT of a sign on the floor of t foyer. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: FOYER.
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - foyer. In the b.g. is a painter, varnishing t floor. He looks up in complete dismay as he sees his newl varnished floor being violated. After a couple of steps, stops, suddenly aware of the painter. The painter rises,  throws down his brush, says something caustic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating painter) Don't mind me, buddy, I just got  through varnishing that floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim reacts, raises a tentative foot, the sticky varnish  practically holding it to the floor. Jim says something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose bright idea was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The painter says something, points at Muriel. Jim looks d and accusingly at Muriel whose weak smile is an admission guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just wanted everything to be  nice and shiny on the day they moved  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim turns and shouts something to the painter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop painting that floor and put  some planks down in here, or some  thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The painter shouts back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, mister, but take it easy. The  Republicans ain't in yet, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim reacts, turns and walks back out of the foyer, desper trying to match his clearly outlined incoming footsteps.  Each step is outlined by strands of thick sticky varnish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim appears, still carrying Muriel, Betsy and Joan cat his attention, indicate the front wall of the house which complete except for the windows. Jim reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine! A house without windows!  We'll just see about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly handing Muriel to Bill he starts off. Ahead of h and unnoticed are a layer of newspapers which have been s out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out for those papers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Jim has stepped on the papers. They stick to his feet After a few steps he is aware of it, tries to get rid of  them. After a few hectic but futile attempts, he disguste disappears around a corner of the house, the newspapers  flapping behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim flaps his way up to a workman who is staring at a pil of window casements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Simms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around back trying to figure out  what to do about them windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem? You put windows  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not these. They don't fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily; control  going) Oh, they don't, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues on toward the back of the house, the newspap flapping beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms and Retch. More window frames are neatly stacked ag the wall. Simms and Retch react as they see an angry Jim  Blandings flap his way into scene, his varnished shoes ha picked up additional paper, shavings, shingles, etc. Retc hands Jim a sheaf of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Blandings, you'd better look  these over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about the windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) I'm afraid there's a little slip-up.  These windows seem to belong to a  Mr. Landings in Fishkill, New York.  I talked to Mr. Landings this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, has he got mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he seems to have some windows  that belong to a Mr. Blandsworth of  Peekskill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are my windows?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As near as we can figure out they've  either been sent to a Mr. Benton in  Evanston, Illinois, or a Mr. Bamberger  of Phoenix, Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill wanders into scene, looks over Jim's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we supposed to do -- live  the rest of our lives in a house  without windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll just be a matter of a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a "Zuz-Zuz Water Soft-N-R"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) You've got one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from bill) "Furnishing and installing one Zuz- Zuz Water Soft-N-R, two hundred and  eighty dollars!" (explosively) I will not have any such piece of  equipment in my house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I authorized that, Mr.  Blandings -- to save your boiler and  water pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rust. The plumbing man assures us  the water from your well is the most  corrosive in his entire experience  in the trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pursing his lips) Mm. (irritably) Well, if it's necessary, put it in!  We're moving in today, you know and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (a final show of  authority; sharply) Then get me the bill for it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating bill) You've got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he stalks off, his papers, shavings, etc. flapping be him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moving vans are driving away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A general flurry of activity; Gussie and several workmen  carrying furniture upstairs, unpacking barrels, etc. Muri list and samples in hand, is explaining her color scheme Mr. PeDelford, a polite, cigar-smoking, noncommittal boss painter. In the b.g., casually leaning on the bannister i PeDelford's taciturn and somewhat skeptical-looking assis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I want the living room to be a  soft green. (PeDelford nods) Not quite as bluish as a robin's  egg, but yet not as yellow as daffodil  buds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a sample) The best sample I could get is a  little too yellow, but don't let  whoever mixes it go to the other  extreme and get it too blue. It should  just be sort of a grayish yellow  green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a note) Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the dining room I'd like yellow.  Not just yellow, a very gay yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something bright and sunshiny. (sudden inspiration) I tell you, Mr. PeDelford, if you'll  just send one of your workmen to the  A&P for a pound of their best butter  and match it exactly, you can't go  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a note) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the paper we're going to use  here in the foyer. (hands sample to him) It's flowered but I don't want the  ceiling to match any of the colors  of the flowers. There are some little  dots in the background, and it's  these dots I want you to match. Not  the little greenish dots near the  hollyhock leaf, but the little bluish  dot between the rosebud and the  delphinium blossom. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PeDelford looks carefully at the sample, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making note) Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen's to be white. Not a  cold, antiseptic hospital white -- a  little warmer but not to suggest any  other color but white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (note) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for the powder room, I want you  to match this thread. (hands him thread) You can see it's practically an apple  red. Somewhere between a healthy  Winesap and an unripened Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making note) Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a crash from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel hastily exits toward the kitchen. PeDelford turns his assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan; indicating  rooms with his thumb) Green, yellow, blue, white, red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan is on a stepladder helping Gussie put away some dish Remains of two broken plates are on the floor below them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, you know father was to take  care of the heavy dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappeared. I haven't seen him  for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy flies into the room waving a railroad timetable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Uncle Bill? I just checked  the timetable -- he's going to miss  his train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they've run off somewhere it  certainly isn't very -- (suddenly stops,  listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From upstairs comes the SOUND of a steady, methodical thu of a hand on a solid oak door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS LANDING
dialogues.text: Muriel opens the closet door revealing Jim and Bill, who  have been locked in the closet for the last hour. Each le against the wall, arms folded, in an attitude of boredom disgust. Without a word Jim and Bill exit from the closet The three start down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly) I thought you were going to take  care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from below) You're going to miss your train,  Uncle Bill! It leaves Lansdale in  twenty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there a later one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not till the Commuter's Special  tomorrow morning at six-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean seven-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dad, six-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the seven-fifteen I'm  supposed to take to the office every  morning?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting timetable) There's a little asterisk. The seven- fifteen only runs Saturdays, Sundays  and holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking timetable) Let me see that! (scans table,  tightlipped) Muriel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, don't tell me I read it  wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine! For the rest of my life  I'm going to have to get up at five  o'clock in the morning to catch the  six-fifteen, to get to my office by  eight, which doesn't even open until  nine -- and which I never get to  until ten!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you started earlier you  could quit earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) So I could get home earlier to go to  bed earlier to get up earlier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can have the railroad push  the train up to four-fifteen -- then  you won't have to go to bed at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Bill, you're going to miss  your train!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, you clean up this mess. I'll  drive Bill to the station and pick  up some cold cuts for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy and Joan pick up some boxes and walk into the dinin room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating upstairs  closet) Kind of hate to leave that little  place. Just four walls and a couple  of mothballs, but to me it'll always  be home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied with  timetable) So long, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Muriel exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim drifts in, still preoccupied with timetable:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's certainly going to be fun this  summer when Uncle Bill comes up for  his vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get in a lot of doubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? (looks up from  timetable) What are you talking about? Bill's  going to Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not. I heard him and mother  talking. He's going to move his  vacation up and take a place in  Lansdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely annoyed) Uh-huh... Mm-hm. Mm-hm... Uh-huh. (then, covering up) All right, come on, come on. Get  busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening is beginning to fall as Muriel drives Bill into t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll scout around and find you a  place in Lansdale. (quickly) Now, you're not going to change your  mind about coming up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll be on the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't be easy. I promise you a  Cook's tour of every lamp maker, rug  weaver, and antique shop in Lansdale  County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (philosophically) When I married you two I suppose I  took you for better or for worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel smiles warmly, and in a friendly gesture reaches o and pats his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Uncle Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Good old Uncle Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they exchange an understanding smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark outside and getting quite chilly. The children are unpacking a last barrel. They have made a rather unst pile of books and boxes, obviously Muriel's personal effe Jim is in the process of trying to start his first fire i the fireplace. The immediate result is a clouding of the  room with smoke. As he backs away, coughing, he bumps int the pile which falls to the floor spilling open a box whi contains, among other things, Muriel's diary and a lifeti accumulation of sentimental trinkets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look what you've done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy coughs her way to the fireplace, turns the flue han The smoke immediately goes up the chimney and the room st to clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, the first principle of  lighting a fire is to see if the  flue is open. A three-year-old child  knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time we want a fire I'll send  out for a three-year-old child! (indicates trinkets) Get that stuff cleaned up and go in  and help Gussie set the table. It's  getting late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children start gathering up the debris. Joan picks up some trinkets which have spilled from a cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Dad, your fraternity pins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy cleaning the  fireplace) Pins? I only had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two of them here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Just put them  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examining them) Funny, this one says W.C. on the  back. W.C.? (brightly) William Cole! It must be Uncle Bill's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? (reaching for it) Let me see that. (examining pin) Hmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy has picked up a small leather-bound book. She whist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother's diary when she was in  college. It's slightly torrid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over) Let's see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) That's none of your business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scanning page) I'd say mother and Uncle Bill were  somewhat of an item!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking book from  Betsy) People do not read other people's  diaries! It's not a very nice thing  to do! (shooting them out) Now go in there and help Gussie with  the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating debris) What about --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of that. Now, shoo,  shoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children exit. Jim is about to put down the diary whe his curiosity gets the better of him. Making sure he's  unobserved, he sits down on a box, opens the book, starts read. As his brows wrinkle with concern:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
