dialogues.text: The wind is howling, the trees swaying. The lights are on the kitchen. CAMERA MOVES UP to the open kitchen window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family, in overcoats, is huddled around the kitchen t finishing dinner. Gussie, in overcoat and muffler, is cle the dishes away. Jim, a sober look on his face, rises, ta a steaming kettle from the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I can still trust myself with  a razor. At six o'clock in the morning  I'd probably cut my throat. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim abruptly exits. Muriel looks after him with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, in his pajamas and overcoat is shaving. After a few  moments Muriel, in her nightgown and overcoat, enters the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her toothbrush and opens the cabinet, Jim  automatically moving around back of it in their previousl established pattern. As Muriel puts the paste on her brus replaces the tube, shuts the cabinet and starts to brush teeth, Jim uncomfortably moves back to his original posit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, do you have to do that now?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need to be so irritable  just because you have to shave at  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not irritable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're certainly something!  You haven't said a civil word all  evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes a man doesn't feel like  talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solicitously) What is it, dear? Something down at  the office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got the new slogan for  "Wham"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not due yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's something. You're certainly  upset about something. I can always  tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not upset. (going back to shaving;  with studied unconcern) It's just that I don't happen to  approve of falsehood and deception.  Particularly in my own wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Oh, nothing. It's just that I  distinctly remember your telling me  you gave back Bill's fraternity pin  fifteen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel looks at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did you or didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I, or didn't I what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I did. If I said I did, I  did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly Sam Spade) Then perhaps you'd have the goodness  to explain how this happened to fall  out of your jewel box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the pin out of his pocket and hands it to her. M takes the pin, looks at it sentimentally. Suddenly she lo at Jim and bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! You're jealous! You're standing  there with your face full of soap  and you're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) If you were so crazy about the guy,  why didn't you marry him?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to be a  little angry) Because I wasn't in love with him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vindictively) That's not what you said in your  diary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now really angry) Oh, now you've been reading my diary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little guilty) Well -- it happened to fall open  and... I... happened to look at it.  It... just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just bet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all over the book so why don't  you admit it? You were in love with  Bill Cole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd! Of course I was in  love with Bill. In those days I was  in love with a new man every week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to wonder! (exploding) Maybe it was those big cow eyes of  yours or that ridiculous hole in  your chin! Maybe I knew that some  day you'd bring me out to this thirty- eight thousand dollar icebox with a  dried-up trout stream and no windows!  Or maybe I just happened to fall in  love with you -- but for heaven's  sake, don't ask me why!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel stalks out of the bathroom. Jim looks after her,  thoughtfully starts to dry his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim enters. Muriel stands with her back to him angrily wi the clock. Jim noisily clears his throat. No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) ...Muriel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it do any good to say I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gently turns her around facing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I am. I acted like a schoolboy  and I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel looks at Jim. Finally she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes into his arms and they kiss intimately. As their lips part:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dreamily) Why don't you take the soap out of  your ears?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Why do I love you so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim again kisses her tenderly, warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) Darling, it's awfully late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim kisses her again, a little more ardently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Maybe you ought to go down and lock  the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing her ear) What for? The windows are all open  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he starts to kiss  her again) Jim, you have to get up at six  o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers; logic  prevails; brief sigh) Yes, I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Goodnight, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same) Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each gets into his own bed, still wearing the overcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - The house now wavers at $37,000 As Jim and Muriel still try to stem the tide, the group t is pushing the house ever upward includes all of the prev people connected with the house and -- in addition --plum painters, landscape gardeners, etc. Over this, and across the scene flutter more bills, more extras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so the days sped by -- and the  bills -- and the extras -- and as  the house approached forty thousand  dollars, Jim approached his deadline  for the new slogan. It was almost a  photo finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining. The lights are on in the buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is attending to some detail work as the door opens a Jim enters, disturbed. Mary looks at him questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better send out for coffee and  sandwiches,... It looks like an all  night session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily, seating  himself at desk) Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well, I guess you'll just have to  dream something up -- good or bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rather got the impression it had  better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raised eyebrow) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a pencil, nibbles on it thoughtfully. The sil in the room is broken only by the patter of raindrops on window. It strikes a note in Jim's subconscious. He swive around in his chair and stares soberly out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruminatively, almost  to himself) Funny how you look forward to the  little things. Rain, for instance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him curiously. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a month now, I guess I've been  looking forward to the first rainy  night at the house. (looks at Muriel's  picture) Big blazing fire. Muriel knitting.  Me in my new smoking jacket... with  my pipe and slippers, reading my  paper... (sighs) Oh, well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: The house is painted and almost completely furnishe A hard rain beats on the windows. There is a blazing fire the fireplace. Muriel, in a warm bathrobe, sits near it,  comfortably knitting. In fact, the scene is exactly the o Jim has just described, except that the man with slippers pipe and smoking jacket, reading the paper, is Bill Cole. Near the fire, Bill's rain-drenched jacket, shirt and sho are hanging up to dry. The cozy tranquillity is broken by sharp RINGING of the front doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with relief) Thank heavens! The children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Stay put. You look too comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA FOLLOWS Bill to the front door. He opens it. A man in raincoat and boots stands there in the pouring, dr rain. The man enters as Bill struggles to get the door sh against the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew! What a night! I'm Jones, from  down the road. Just came over to  tell you your kids are all right,  Mr. Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not Mr. Blandings. Cole's  the name, Bill Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Jones' doubtful look at the smoking jacket, feels explanation is necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend of the family. Wet clothes.  Just came in out of the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel walks into scene. Jones takes in the bathrobe, aga looks skeptically at Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mrs. Blandings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do. Mrs. Williams just called.  Says your phone's out of order. Wanted  me to tell you the water's rising  and they've got the bridge roped  off. Girls'll spend the night over  at her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I was beginning to get  concerned. Can I make you a cup of  tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks. Better be gettin' back  'fore I have to swim for it. 'Night,  Mrs. Blandings. (to Bill) 'Night, Mr. Bl--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weak smile) Cole. Bill Cole. Friend of the family.  Just came in out of the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) Well -- 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight... and thanks so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is opened with a terrific swirl of wind and rain Jones exits as Muriel and Bill push the door against the  wind, finally getting it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. No bridge. How do I get  back to Lansdale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) You'll just have to spend the night  right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start back into the living room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel, really! With your husband in  New York and your children away --  think of my reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smile) Don't worry, Snow White, you'll be  as pure and unsullied in the morning  as you were the night before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with resignation) That's the story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel pokes the dying fire, looks up thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Jim, he sounded so worried  before. I certainly hope he comes up  with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the man who gave  the world "When you've got the whim,  say Wham!"-- This well will never  run dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA COMES IN ON a package of cigarettes. A finger  impatiently rips open what is left of the package, disclo that it is empty. The ANGLE WIDENS to reveal a tired,  disheveled Jim. Disgusted, he fishes the most likely butt from a tray littered with them. With considerable difficu he manages to light it, only to burn his nose. Impatientl stamping out the butt he rises, stretches, walks to the  window, pulls up the shade. Early morning sunlight floods the room. He turns off a standing lamp, looks thoughtfull out the window, suddenly gets an idea. Turning, he snaps fingers. Mary, who is asleep on the desk, her head restin on her elbows, raises her head, opens a sleepy eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (selling; a note of  desperation in his  voice) "Compare the price, compare the slice,  Take our advice -- Buy Wham!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary critically shakes her head "no", closes her eye. Jim wearily throws himself down on the couch, absently toys w his already loosened tie. He pulls it up over his nose,  throwing the balance over the top of his head. Suddenly h reacts, snaps his fingers. Mary opens a sleepy eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If you'd buy better ham. You'd better  buy Wham!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Boyle Petroleum. "If you'd buy  better oil, You'd better buy Boyle."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eye closes. Jim sinks back with defeat, his hand drop over the edge of the couch. It encounters a crumpled piec of paper, earlier work. He smoothes the paper, scans it,  kind of likes it. He gets up, comes over, snaps fingers.  Mary looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This little pig went to market As  meek and as mild as a lamb. He smiled  in his tracks When they slipped him  the axe He knew he'd turn out to be  Wham!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silent look passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) "...knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly and angrily gathers all his papers, slams the into the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising panic) It's gone! I've lost my touch! Maybe  I never had a touch! Maybe "Whim Say  Wham" was an accident! Who knows? I  can't think any more! All I've got  on my mind is a house with an eighteen  thousand dollar mortgage, and bills,  and extras, and antiques, and -- and -- (dejected) I don't know... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at him sympathetically, doesn't quite know wha to say. As the CAMERA MOVES to a CLOSE SHOT of the emotio distraught Jim, his eyes go to a large photograph on his  desk of Muriel and the children. He picks it up, looks at with affection. Suddenly he gets an idea. Rising with  determination he puts on his coat and starts for the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home, to get some sleep -- and I'd  advise you to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- but you haven't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I haven't! This isn't the  only job in town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But -- but -- what'll I tell Mr.  Dascomb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) You just tell him to -- to -- (with finality) You just tell him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an especially beautiful, sunshiny morning. A rural- looking taxi deposits a weary Jim, who pays the driver. A the cab drives off, Jim looks speculatively at Simms' car which is parked there, yawns, stretches, opens the door a enters. Under this a slightly sour underscoring of "Home The Range."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim comes into the foyer, he sees Muriel, in nightgown and robe, talking to Mr. Simms. She holds the rolled-up v of blueprints that went into building the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to him;  solicitously) Darling, you must be exhausted. How  did it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obliquely) Is... everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastic) Everything's fine. (still in embrace;  looking up) Hello, Simms, what brings you out  with the morning dew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just dropped by to check the  blueprints. Some extras came in from  Retch this morning and there're a  couple of things I thought we ought  to go over together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arms still around  Muriel; unconcerned) Really. What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see. (thumbing through  sheets) Few little things here, all right, I  guess. "Mortising five butts -- a  dollar sixty-eight."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not quibble about that. A man's  entitled to mortise a few butts now  and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (next sheet) Extra nails and screws -- three  dollars, eighty-nine cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petty larceny, but let him get away  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's one here I frankly don't  understand. Ah, here we are. (reads) "Changes in closet, twelve hundred  and forty-seven dollars." Did you  authorize that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we probably told him to -- (reacting) Twelve hundred and what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-seven dollars. Changes in  closet. (hands bill to Jim)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively) Who does he think we are! (looks at bill; very  businesslike) What's this notation: "Refer to Detail  Sheet Number one thirty-five?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating blueprints) Far as I remember, that would be  something in the back of the house.  Let's just take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he unrolls the blueprints, Jim looks suspiciously at  Muriel. She seems a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, here we are. It isn't a closet  at all. It's off the back pantry...  Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Mrs. Blandings' little flower  sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Muriel) You didn't authorize any changes,  did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Well... they certainly weren't  changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- have -- you -- done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking rapidly a  little confused) I haven't done anything! And what I  did was... just nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- have -- you -- done?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- (rattling off) All I did was one day I saw four  pieces of flagstone left over from  the porch that were just going to be  thrown away because nobody wanted  them and I asked Mr. Retch if he  wouldn't just put them down on the  floor of the flower sink and poke a  little cement between the cracks and  give me a nice stone floor where it  might be wet with flowers and things.  That was absolutely all I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the above speech Simms sinks into a chair, puts hi head in his hands and closes his eyes, a fact that isn't  lost on Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Just four little pieces  of flagstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Muriel; wearily) Did you by any chance authorize a  drain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (verge of tears) Of course I didn't. All I said was I  wanted a nice stone floor and Mr.  Retch was just as nice as could be  and said, "You're the doctor," and  that's all anybody ever said to  anybody about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes a deep breath, turns to Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh; plunging in) All right, I think I can tell you  what happened. First, the carpenters  had to rip up the flooring that was  already laid. Those planks run under  the whole width of the pantry, so  Retch had to knock the bottom out of  the pantry wall to get at them.

dialogues.speaker: JIM AND MURIEL
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel - Jim looks at Muriel as though he were  premeditating first-degree murder. She averts his gaze. O this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he had to chop out the tops of  the joists under the flower sink  space to make room for a cradle. I  guess he bought some iron straps and  fastened them to a big pan to give  him something to hold the cement.  What with that added load on the  weakened joists, I'll bet he had to  put a lally column down there for  support, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just four little pieces of  flagstone, and I only ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: DURING THE FOLLOWING SPEECH
dialogues.text: GROUP SHOT - During the following speech we see Bill Cole in Jim's pajamas and robe come down the stairs and enter room. Jim and Muriel are not aware of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the main soil pipe runs under  there on wall brackets, so Retch had  to get his plumbing man back to take  out a section so he could get that  cradle set. I guess that meant he  had to change the pitch of the soil  pipe from one end of the house to  the other. (looks up) 'Morning, Mr. Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning. Hello, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Hello, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim turns away, reacts, suddenly turns back to Bill, taki in the pajamas and robe. A little shocked but unwilling t believe the implication of what he sees, he looks to Muri for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lamely) The bridge was roped off and Bill  had to stay last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Slept like a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Bill, then back at Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat) And then, of course, there are hot  and cold water pipes hooked to the  joists right under that pantry. They  go up to the wing bathroom on the  second floor, and I'll bet my bottom  dollar he had to relocate them.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, MURIEL AND BILL.
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT - Jim, Muriel and Bill. Jim turns to listen bu finds himself looking speculatively at Muriel and Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I guess the electrician had to  rip out about sixty feet of armored  cable between the main panel and the  junction box by the oil burner,  including the two hundred twenty  volt cable that goes to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: GUSSIE APPEARS IN THE DOORWAY
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT - Gussie appears in the doorway in raincoat,  carrying umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, everybody. Whew! What a  night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lansdale. Couldn't get back across  the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... weren't here last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't letting anybody across  that bridge, Mr. Blandings. (to Muriel) I passed the girls over at the  Williams. They'll be along any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jim reacts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Thank you, Gussie. You'd better get  breakfast started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gussie exits, Muriel turns to Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were at the two hundred twenty  volt cable that goes to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. (looks at Bill, then  at Muriel) You mean the children weren't here  last night either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could they be, dear? The bridge  was closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came across it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was closed last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly) It's open now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempt at breeziness) If you'll all excuse me -- I -- I  think I'll just go up and slip into  something a little more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill exits. Another pause. Simms, aware of the tension, w to get out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Well, that's about the size of it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through Simms' speech, Jim looks darkly at Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- except that Retch had to repair  the pantry wall and that meant getting  a plasterer back. And of course, he  couldn't have broken through that  wall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Simms, all right. We'll  take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preparing to exit) I'll admit it's a little steep. But  I'll try to get Retch to knock a  hundred dollars off the bill. If I  can't get that, I'll certainly try  for seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he doesn't go for seventy-five,  I'll take a stab at fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) Anyway, I'm almost sure we can get  twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lamely) Well. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. There is a deadly pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Now dear, you're upset, you've got a  lot of things on your mind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with dangerous calm) Muriel, there's only one thing on my  mind -- This house -- and how fast  we can get rid of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's not. Maybe I'm thinking I  was once a happy man! (the martyr) I didn't have a closet, I didn't  have three bathrooms, but I did have  my sanity, a few dollars in the bank,  two children who loved me and a wife  I could trust!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fine thing to say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also had a job at Danton and  Bascomb, something I don't happen to  have at the moment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, I've resigned! We're  starting all over again! From scratch!  And without this house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (near tears) You love this house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. Mr. Tesander enters, cap in hand, stands ther nervous and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every word of it! Anybody who builds  a house today is crazy! The minute  you start, they put you on the list.  The All-American Sucker list!  Everywhere you turn they've got a  hand in your pocket. If you take out  their hands, they find more pockets! (explosively) It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a  conspiracy against every man and  woman who want a home of their own!  Against every boy and girl who were  ever in love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tesander clears his throat. Jim turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) What do you want?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight embarrassed pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Well, Mr. Blandings, there's a matter  of twelve dollars and eighty-six  cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wild gleam) Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents!  Why be a piker, Mr. Tesander? (emptying pockets) Take everything I've got! Spread it  out among your pals! (advancing toward the  bewildered Tesander) Wouldn't Retch like a little  something? Maybe Zucca could use my  new dinner jacket? It's open house,  Mr. Tesander! Help yourself! If this  isn't enough I'll come over to your  place and do some odd chores. Maybe  I can mow your lawn or scratch your  back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) You don't understand, Mr. Blandings.  This twelve dollars and eighty-six  cents -- you don't owe me, I owe  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a momentary pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...W-what was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out money) Found I overcharged you. Almost three  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the money to Jim, who stares at it blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better count it. I think it's all  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks haplessly at Muriel, sheepish, guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Mr. Tesander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'd better be gettin'  along. (looking around) Sure got a pretty place here. (at door; pauses;  looks back) I'll tell Mr. Zucca about the dinner  jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel look at each other a little sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Tesander is about to exit, Bill, dressed, starts down stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Tesander -- could you give  me a lift to town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) What did you mean before about losing  your job? Will we really have to  sell the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserable) I don't know, dear... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case anyone's interested, I'm  leaving for town. (for Jim's benefit) If you want to count the silverware,  I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) Bill, be patient with me. Maybe one  of these days I'll grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Muriel) What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Muriel look at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've kind of been the voice  of doom about this whole project.  Every step of the way I was firmly  convinced you were getting fleeced,  bilked, rooked, flimflammed and  generally taken to the cleaners. And  maybe you were. Maybe it cost you a  whole lot more than you thought it  would. Maybe there were times when  you wished you'd never started the  whole thing. But when I look around  and see what you two have here -- I  don't know. (pause) Maybe there are some things you should  buy with your heart and not with  your head. Maybe those are the things  that really count... See you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bill turns and leaves, the outer door is heard opening and the kids appear. There is an exchange of "Hi's" as th pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hi, Dad! How come you're not at the  office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look at Muriel) I'm on a... kind of a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you got fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not exactly, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll discuss it later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie's head appears from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Come and get it! Breakfast everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! I'm starving! What are we  having, Gussie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orange juice, scrambled eggs and you- know-what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a face) Ham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ham -- Wham! (cheerily) If you ain't eatin' Wham, you ain't  eatin' ham!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gussie's head disappears. CLOSE SHOT - JIM. CLOSE SHOT - Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts with the sudden exhilaration of Balboa first se the Pacific. He snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, give Gussie a ten dollar  raise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes light up as he begins to visualize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT ADVERTISEMENT IN MAGAZINE - It is a picture of Gus smiling, holding a platter with an enormous ham. Under it the simple caption: "IF YOU AIN'T EATIN' WHAM, YOU AIN'T EATIN' HAM!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to disclose Mr. James Blandings  reclining in a hammock on the patio of his Dream House. I the b.g. Muriel is working at her garden, Joan and Betsy  assisting her. Jim reacts with pride and satisfaction as sets the magazine down, takes a long drink of lemonade an picks up a book which he has been reading. As the CAMERA  COMES IN for an EXTREME CLOSE SHOT of Jim we see the titl of the book on the jacket cover. It reads: "MR. BLANDINGS BUILDS HIS DREAM HOUSE"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks up over the top of the book, directly into the  camera and winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with simple sincerity) Drop in and see us sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CAMERA PULLS AWAY to a LONG SHOT tableau of the  Blandings and their Dream House, we:
